<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Paris" title="wikt:Paris">Wiktionary</a> for the name of Paris in various languages other than English and French.</div>
<p>The ancient <a href="/wiki/Oppidum" title="Oppidum">oppidum</a> that corresponds to the modern city of Paris was first mentioned in the mid-1st century BC by <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a> as <i>Luteciam Parisiorum</i> ('<a href="/wiki/Lutetia" title="Lutetia">Lutetia</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parisii_(France)" title="Parisii (France)">Parisii</a>')<i>,</i> and is later attested as <i>Parision</i> in the 5th century AD, then as <i>Paris</i> in 1265.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENègre1990155_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENègre1990155-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falileyev_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Falileyev-17">[17]</a></sup> During the Roman period, it was commonly known as <i>Lutetia</i> or <i>Lutecia</i> in Latin, and as <i>Leukotekía</i> in Greek, which is interpreted as either stemming from the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic</a> root <i>*lukot-</i> ('mouse'), or from *<i>luto-</i> ('marsh, swamp'), depending on whether the Latin or Greek form is the closest to the original <a href="/wiki/Gaulish" title="Gaulish">Gaulish</a> name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambert199438_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambert199438-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003211_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003211-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falileyev_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Falileyev-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name <i>Paris</i> is derived from its early inhabitants, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parisii_(France)" title="Parisii (France)">Parisii</a> (Gaulish: <i>Parisioi</i>), a <a href="/wiki/Gauls" title="Gauls">Gallic</a> tribe from the <a href="/wiki/La_T%C3%A8ne_culture" title="La Tène culture">Iron Age</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_period" title="Roman period">Roman period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003247_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003247-20">[20]</a></sup> The meaning of the Gaulish <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> remains debated. According to <a href="/wiki/Xavier_Delamarre" title="Xavier Delamarre">Xavier Delamarre</a>, it may derive from the Celtic root <i>pario-</i> ('cauldron').<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003247_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDelamarre2003247-20">[20]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Holder" title="Alfred Holder">Alfred Holder</a> interpreted the name as 'the makers' or 'the commanders', by comparing it to the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> <i>peryff</i> ('lord, commander'), both possibly descending from a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Celtic" title="Proto-Celtic">Proto-Celtic</a> form reconstructed as *<i>kwar-is-io</i>-.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusse2006199_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusse2006199-21">[21]</a></sup> Alternatively, <a href="/wiki/Pierre-Yves_Lambert" title="Pierre-Yves Lambert">Pierre-Yves Lambert</a> proposed to translate <i>Parisii</i> as the 'spear people', by connecting the first element to the <a href="/wiki/Old_Irish" title="Old Irish">Old Irish</a> <i>carr</i> ('spear'), derived from an earlier *<i>kwar-sā</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Falileyev_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-Falileyev-17">[17]</a></sup> In any case, the city's name is not related to the <a href="/wiki/Paris_(mythology)" title="Paris (mythology)">Paris</a> of <a href="/wiki/Greek_mythology" title="Greek mythology">Greek mythology</a>.
</p><p>Paris is often referred to as the 'City of Light' (<i>La Ville Lumière</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobertson201037_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobertson201037-22">[22]</a></sup> both because of its leading role during the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> and more literally because Paris was one of the first large European cities to use gas <a href="/wiki/Street_light" title="Street light">street lighting</a> on a grand scale on its boulevards and monuments. <a href="/wiki/Gas_lighting" title="Gas lighting">Gas lights</a> were installed on the <a href="/wiki/Place_du_Carrousel" title="Place du Carrousel">Place du Carrousel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rue_de_Rivoli" title="Rue de Rivoli">Rue de Rivoli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Place_Vend%C3%B4me" title="Place Vendôme">Place Vendome</a> in 1829. By 1857, the Grand boulevards were lit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> By the 1860s, the boulevards and streets of Paris were illuminated by 56,000 gas lamps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDu_Camp1875596_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDu_Camp1875596-24">[24]</a></sup> Since the late 19th century, Paris has also been known as <i>Panam(e)</i> (<small>pronounced </small><span class="IPA" lang="fr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">[panam]</a></span>) in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argot" title="Argot">French slang</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeclanche199855_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeclanche199855-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The reason for this is unclear. (April 2022)">why?</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Inhabitants are known in English as "Parisians" and in French as <i>Parisiens</i> (<small></small><span class="IPA" lang="fr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">[paʁizjɛ̃]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parisien2.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Parisien2.ogg" title="Parisien2.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>). They are also pejoratively called <i>Parigots</i> (<small></small><span class="IPA" lang="fr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">[paʁiɡo]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parigot.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Parigot.ogg" title="Parigot.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[note 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDottin1920535_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDottin1920535-27">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Paris" title="History of Paris">History of Paris</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Paris" title="Timeline of Paris">Timeline of Paris</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Origins">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Lutetia" title="Lutetia">Lutetia</a></div>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Parisii_(Gaul)" title="Parisii (Gaul)">Parisii</a></i>, a sub-tribe of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celt" title="Celt">Celtic</a> <a href="/wiki/Senones" title="Senones">Senones</a>, inhabited the Paris area from around the middle of the 3rd century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbois_de_JubainvilleDottin1889132_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbois_de_JubainvilleDottin1889132-28">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe2004201_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe2004201-29">[28]</a></sup> One of the area's major north–south trade routes crossed the Seine on the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">île de la Cité</a>; this meeting place of land and water trade routes gradually became an important trading centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201025_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201025-30">[29]</a></sup> The Parisii traded with many river towns (some as far away as the Iberian Peninsula) and minted their own coins for that purpose.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt200965–70_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt200965–70-31">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ParisiiCoins.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="528" data-file-width="1028" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/ParisiiCoins.jpg/330px-ParisiiCoins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/ParisiiCoins.jpg/495px-ParisiiCoins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/ParisiiCoins.jpg/660px-ParisiiCoins.jpg 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ParisiiCoins.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gold coins minted by the Parisii (1st century BC)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> conquered the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Basin" title="Paris Basin">Paris Basin</a> in 52 BC and began their settlement on Paris's <a href="/wiki/Rive_Gauche" title="Rive Gauche">Left Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt200988–104_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt200988–104-32">[31]</a></sup> The Roman town was originally called <a href="/wiki/Lutetia" title="Lutetia">Lutetia</a> (more fully, <i>Lutetia Parisiorum</i>, "Lutetia of the Parisii", modern French <i>Lutèce</i>). It became a prosperous city with a forum, baths, temples, theatres, and an <a href="/wiki/Amphitheatre" title="Amphitheatre">amphitheatre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009154–167_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009154–167-33">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a>, the town was known as <i>Parisius</i>, a Latin name that would later become <i>Paris</i> in French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeunier201412_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeunier201412-34">[33]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> was introduced in the middle of the 3rd century AD by Saint <a href="/wiki/Saint_Denis_of_Paris" title="Saint Denis of Paris">Denis</a>, the first Bishop of Paris: according to legend, when he refused to renounce his faith before the Roman occupiers, he was beheaded on the hill which became known as <i>Mons Martyrum</i> (Latin "Hill of Martyrs"), later "<a href="/wiki/Montmartre" title="Montmartre">Montmartre</a>", from where he walked headless to the north of the city; the place where he fell and was buried became an important religious shrine, the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Saint-Denis" title="Basilica of Saint-Denis">Basilica of Saint-Denis</a>, and many French kings are buried there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009210–211_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009210–211-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Clovis_I" title="Clovis I">Clovis the Frank</a>, the first king of the <a href="/wiki/Merovingian_dynasty" title="Merovingian dynasty">Merovingian dynasty</a>, made the city his capital from 508.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup> As the Frankish domination of Gaul began, there was a gradual immigration by the <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Franks</a> to Paris and the Parisian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Francien" title="Francien">Francien</a> dialects were born. Fortification of the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a> failed to avert <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Paris_(845)" title="Siege of Paris (845)">sacking by Vikings in 845</a>, but Paris's strategic importance—with its bridges preventing ships from passing—was established by successful defence in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Paris_(885%E2%80%93886)" title="Siege of Paris (885–886)">Siege of Paris (885–886)</a>, for which the then <a href="/wiki/Count_of_Paris" title="Count of Paris">Count of Paris</a> (<i>comte de Paris</i>), <a href="/wiki/Odo_of_France" title="Odo of France">Odo of France</a>, was elected king of <a href="/wiki/West_Francia" title="West Francia">West Francia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones199448_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones199448-37">[36]</a></sup> From the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Capet" title="House of Capet">Capetian</a> dynasty that began with the 987 election of <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Capet" title="Hugh Capet">Hugh Capet</a>, Count of Paris and <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_the_Franks" title="Duke of the Franks">Duke of the Franks</a> (<i>duc des Francs</i>), as king of a unified West Francia, Paris gradually became the largest and most prosperous city in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009210–211_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt2009210–211-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="High_and_Late_Middle_Ages_to_Louis_XIV">High and Late Middle Ages to Louis XIV</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: High and Late Middle Ages to Louis XIV">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Paris in the Middle Ages">Paris in the Middle Ages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_the_16th_century" title="Paris in the 16th century">Paris in the 16th century</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_the_17th_century" title="Paris in the 17th century">Paris in the 17th century</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg"><img alt="The Palais de la Cité and Sainte-Chapelle, viewed from the Left Bank, from the Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry (month of June) (1410)" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="757" data-file-width="1127" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg/220px-Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg/330px-Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg/440px-Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palais_de_la_Cite.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palais_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Palais de la Cité">Palais de la Cité</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sainte-Chapelle" title="Sainte-Chapelle">Sainte-Chapelle</a>, viewed from the Left Bank, from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tr%C3%A8s_Riches_Heures_du_duc_de_Berry" title="Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry">Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry</a> (month of June) (1410)</div></div></div>
<p>By the end of the 12th century, Paris had become the political, economic, religious, and cultural capital of France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201027_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201027-38">[37]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Palais_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Palais de la Cité">Palais de la Cité</a>, the royal residence, was located at the western end of the Île de la Cité. In 1163, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Louis_VII_of_France" title="Louis VII of France">Louis VII</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maurice_de_Sully" title="Maurice de Sully">Maurice de Sully</a>, bishop of Paris, undertook the construction of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre Dame de Paris">Notre Dame Cathedral</a> at its eastern extremity.
</p><p>After the marshland between the river Seine and its slower 'dead arm' to its north was filled in from around the 10th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBussmann198522_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBussmann198522-39">[38]</a></sup> Paris's cultural centre began to move to the Right Bank. In 1137, a new city marketplace (today's <a href="/wiki/Les_Halles" title="Les Halles">Les Halles</a>) replaced the two smaller ones on the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a> and <a href="/wiki/Place_de_l%27H%C3%B4tel-de-Ville_%E2%80%93_Esplanade_de_la_Lib%C3%A9ration" title="Place de l'Hôtel-de-Ville – Esplanade de la Libération">Place de Grève (Place de l'Hôtel de Ville)</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEde_VitriacoHinnebusch1972262_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEde_VitriacoHinnebusch1972262-40">[39]</a></sup> The latter location housed the headquarters of Paris's river trade corporation, an organisation that later became, unofficially (although formally in later years), Paris's first municipal government.
</p><p>In the late 12th century, <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_France" title="Philip II of France">Philip Augustus</a> extended the <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a> fortress to defend the city against river invasions from the west, gave the city its first walls between 1190 and 1215, rebuilt its bridges to either side of its central island, and paved its main thoroughfares.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant201236–40_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant201236–40-41">[40]</a></sup> In 1190, he transformed Paris's former cathedral school into a student-teacher corporation that would become the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">University of Paris</a> and would draw students from all of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant201228–29_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant201228–29-42">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201027_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201027-38">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>With 200,000 inhabitants in 1328, Paris, then already the capital of France, was the most populous city of Europe. By comparison, London in 1300 had 80,000 inhabitants.
</p><p>By the early fourteenth century so much filth had collected inside urban Europe that French and Italian cities were naming streets after human waste. In medieval Paris, several street names were inspired by merde, the French word for “shit.” There were rue Merdeux, rue Merdelet, rue Merdusson, rue des Merdons, and rue Merdiere—as well as a rue du Pipi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ParisDigest_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-ParisDigest-44">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1412" data-file-width="1488" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG/220px-P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG/330px-P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG/440px-P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P1030887_Paris_IV_h%C3%B4tel_de_Sens_rwk.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_de_Sens" title="Hôtel de Sens">Hôtel de Sens</a> (15th-16th c.) former residence of the Archbishop of Sens</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_War" title="Hundred Years' War">Hundred Years' War</a>, Paris was occupied by England-friendly <a href="/wiki/Burgundian_State" title="Burgundian State">Burgundian forces</a> from 1418, before being occupied outright by the English when <a href="/wiki/Henry_V_of_England" title="Henry V of England">Henry V of England</a> entered the French capital in 1420;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[44]</a></sup> in spite of a 1429 effort by <a href="/wiki/Joan_of_Arc" title="Joan of Arc">Joan of Arc</a> to liberate the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro199652–53_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro199652–53-46">[45]</a></sup> it would remain under English occupation until 1436.
</p><p>In the late 16th-century <a href="/wiki/French_Wars_of_Religion" title="French Wars of Religion">French Wars of Religion</a>, Paris was a stronghold of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_League_(French)" title="Catholic League (French)">Catholic League</a>, the organisers of 24 August 1572 <a href="/wiki/St._Bartholomew%27s_Day_massacre" title="St. Bartholomew's Day massacre">St. Bartholomew's Day massacre</a> in which thousands of French Protestants were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBayrou1994121–130_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBayrou1994121–130-48">[47]</a></sup> The conflicts ended when pretender to the throne <a href="/wiki/Henry_IV_of_France" title="Henry IV of France">Henry IV</a>, after converting to Catholicism to gain entry to the capital, entered the city in 1594 to claim the crown of France. This king made several improvements to the capital during his reign: he completed the construction of Paris's first uncovered, sidewalk-lined bridge, the <a href="/wiki/Pont_Neuf" title="Pont Neuf">Pont Neuf</a>, built a Louvre extension connecting it to the <a href="/wiki/Tuileries_Palace" title="Tuileries Palace">Tuileries Palace</a>, and created the first Paris residential square, the Place Royale, now <a href="/wiki/Place_des_Vosges" title="Place des Vosges">Place des Vosges</a>. In spite of Henry IV's efforts to improve city circulation, the narrowness of Paris's streets was a contributing factor in his assassination near <a href="/wiki/Les_Halles" title="Les Halles">Les Halles</a> marketplace in 1610.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996577_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996577-49">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 17th century, <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_Richelieu" title="Cardinal Richelieu">Cardinal Richelieu</a>, chief minister of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XIII_of_France" title="Louis XIII of France">Louis XIII</a>, was determined to make Paris the most beautiful city in Europe. He built five new bridges, a new chapel for the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Sorbonne" title="College of Sorbonne">College of Sorbonne</a>, and a palace for himself, the <a href="/wiki/Palais-Royal" title="Palais-Royal">Palais-Cardinal</a>, which he bequeathed to Louis XIII. After Richelieu's death in 1642, it was renamed the <a href="/wiki/Palais-Royal" title="Palais-Royal">Palais-Royal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996582_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996582-50">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4605" data-file-width="5500" decoding="async" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG/220px-Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG/330px-Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG/440px-Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plan_de_Paris_en_1657.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lutetia Parisiorum vulgo Paris, Plan de Paris en 1657, <a href="/wiki/Jan_Janssonius" title="Jan Janssonius">Jan Janssonius</a></div></div></div>
<p>Due to the Parisian uprisings during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fronde" title="Fronde">Fronde</a> civil war, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV</a> moved his court to a new palace, <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Versailles</a>, in 1682. Although no longer the capital of France, arts and sciences in the city flourished with the <a href="/wiki/Com%C3%A9die-Fran%C3%A7aise" title="Comédie-Française">Comédie-Française</a>, the Academy of Painting, and the <a href="/wiki/French_Academy_of_Sciences" title="French Academy of Sciences">French Academy of Sciences</a>. To demonstrate that the city was safe from attack, the king had the <a href="/wiki/City_walls_of_Paris" title="City walls of Paris">city walls</a> demolished and replaced with tree-lined boulevards that would become the <i><a href="/wiki/Boulevards_of_Paris#The_grands_boulevards" title="Boulevards of Paris">Grands Boulevards</a></i> of today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECombeau200342–43_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECombeau200342–43-51">[50]</a></sup> Other marks of his reign were the <a href="/wiki/Coll%C3%A8ge_des_Quatre-Nations" title="Collège des Quatre-Nations">Collège des Quatre-Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Place_Vend%C3%B4me" title="Place Vendôme">Place Vendôme</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Place_des_Victoires" title="Place des Victoires">Place des Victoires</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Les_Invalides" title="Les Invalides">Les Invalides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996590–591_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996590–591-52">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="18th_and_19th_centuries">18th and 19th centuries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: 18th and 19th centuries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_the_18th_century" title="Paris in the 18th century">Paris in the 18th century</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_during_the_Second_Empire" title="Paris during the Second Empire">Paris during the Second Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Haussmann%27s_renovation_of_Paris" title="Haussmann's renovation of Paris">Haussmann's renovation of Paris</a></div>
<p>Paris grew in population from about 400,000 in 1640 to 650,000 in 1780.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup> A new boulevard, the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a>, extended the city west to <a href="/wiki/Place_Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Place Charles de Gaulle">Étoile</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECombeau200345–47_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECombeau200345–47-54">[53]</a></sup> while the working-class neighbourhood of the <a href="/wiki/Faubourg_Saint-Antoine" title="Faubourg Saint-Antoine">Faubourg Saint-Antoine</a> on the eastern site of the city grew more and more crowded with poor migrant workers from other regions of France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012129–133_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012129–133-55">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5877" data-file-width="7877" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/220px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/330px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/440px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The storming of the <a href="/wiki/Bastille" title="Bastille">Bastille</a> on 14 July 1789, by <a href="/wiki/Jean-Pierre_Hou%C3%ABl" title="Jean-Pierre Houël">Jean-Pierre Houël</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pantheon_2,_Paris_May_11,_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3174" data-file-width="4495" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg/220px-Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg/330px-Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg/440px-Pantheon_2%2C_Paris_May_11%2C_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pantheon_2,_Paris_May_11,_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Panth%C3%A9on" title="Panthéon">Panthéon</a>, a major landmark on the <a href="/wiki/Rive_Gauche" title="Rive Gauche">Rive Gauche</a>, was completed in 1790.</div></div></div>
<p>Paris was the centre of an explosion of philosophic and scientific activity known as the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>. <a href="/wiki/Denis_Diderot" title="Denis Diderot">Diderot</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean_le_Rond_d%27Alembert" title="Jean le Rond d'Alembert">d'Alembert</a> published their <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A9die" title="Encyclopédie">Encyclopédie</a></i> in 1751, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Montgolfier_Brothers" title="Montgolfier Brothers">Montgolfier Brothers</a> launched the first manned flight in a hot-air balloon on 21 November 1783, from the gardens of the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_la_Muette" title="Château de la Muette">Château de la Muette</a>. Paris was the financial capital of continental Europe, the primary European centre of book publishing and fashion and the manufacture of fine furniture and luxury goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012120_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012120-56">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the summer of 1789, Paris became the centre stage for the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>. On 14 July, a mob seized the arsenal at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Invalides" title="Invalides">Invalides</a>, acquiring thousands of guns, and <a href="/wiki/Storming_of_the_Bastille" title="Storming of the Bastille">stormed the Bastille</a>, a symbol of royal authority. The first independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Commune_(French_Revolution)" title="Paris Commune (French Revolution)">Paris Commune</a>, or city council, met in the <i>Hôtel de Ville</i> and, on 15 July, elected a <a href="/wiki/Mayor_(France)" title="Mayor (France)">Mayor</a>, the astronomer <a href="/wiki/Jean_Sylvain_Bailly" title="Jean Sylvain Bailly">Jean Sylvain Bailly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaine1998453_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaine1998453-57">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Louis_XVI" title="Louis XVI">Louis XVI</a> and the royal family <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Women%27s_march_on_Versailles" title="Women's march on Versailles">were brought to Paris</a> and made prisoners within the Tuileries Palace. In 1793, as the revolution turned more and more radical, the king, queen, and the mayor were guillotined (executed) in the <a href="/wiki/Reign_of_Terror" title="Reign of Terror">Reign of Terror</a>, along with more than 16,000 others throughout France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996674_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996674-58">[57]</a></sup> The property of the aristocracy and the church was <a href="/wiki/Biens_nationaux" title="Biens nationaux">nationalised</a>, and the city's churches were closed, sold or demolished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012144_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012144-59">[58]</a></sup> A succession of revolutionary factions ruled Paris until <a href="/wiki/Coup_of_18_Brumaire" title="Coup of 18 Brumaire">9 November 1799</a> (<i>coup d'état du 18 brumaire</i>), when <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoléon Bonaparte</a> seized power as First Consul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012147_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012147-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population of Paris had dropped by 100,000 during the Revolution, but between 1799 and 1815, it surged with 160,000 new residents, reaching 660,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148-61">[60]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> replaced the elected government of Paris with a prefect reporting only to him. He began erecting monuments to military glory, including the <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a>, and improved the neglected infrastructure of the city with new fountains, the <a href="/wiki/Canal_de_l%27Ourcq" title="Canal de l'Ourcq">Canal de l'Ourcq</a>, <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A8re_Lachaise_Cemetery" title="Père Lachaise Cemetery">Père Lachaise Cemetery</a> and the city's first metal bridge, the <a href="/wiki/Pont_des_Arts" title="Pont des Arts">Pont des Arts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148-61">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Louis-Emile_Durandelle,_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction,_1888.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4169" data-file-width="3277" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg/170px-Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg/255px-Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg/340px-Louis-Emile_Durandelle%2C_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction%2C_1888.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Louis-Emile_Durandelle,_The_Eiffel_Tower_-_State_of_the_Construction,_1888.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a>, under construction in November 1888, startled Parisians — and the world — with its modernity.</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Restoration_in_France" title="Bourbon Restoration in France">Restoration</a>, the bridges and squares of Paris were returned to their pre-Revolution names; the <a href="/wiki/July_Revolution" title="July Revolution">July Revolution</a> in 1830 (commemorated by the <a href="/wiki/July_Column" title="July Column">July Column</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Bastille" title="Place de la Bastille">Place de la Bastille</a>) brought a constitutional monarch, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Philippe_I" title="Louis Philippe I">Louis Philippe I</a>, to power. The first railway line to Paris opened in 1837, beginning a new period of massive migration from the <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_France" title="Provinces of France">provinces</a> to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148_61-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012148-61">[60]</a></sup> Louis-Philippe was overthrown by a <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution_of_1848" title="French Revolution of 1848">popular uprising</a> in the streets of Paris in 1848. His successor, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a>, alongside the newly appointed prefect of the Seine, <a href="/wiki/Georges-Eug%C3%A8ne_Haussmann" title="Georges-Eugène Haussmann">Georges-Eugène Haussmann</a>, launched a gigantic public works project to build wide new boulevards, a new opera house, a central market, new aqueducts, sewers and parks, including the <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Boulogne" title="Bois de Boulogne">Bois de Boulogne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Vincennes" title="Bois de Vincennes">Bois de Vincennes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Moncan20127–35_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Moncan20127–35-62">[61]</a></sup> In 1860, Napoleon III also annexed the surrounding towns and created eight new arrondissements, expanding Paris to its current limits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Moncan20127–35_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Moncan20127–35-62">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> (1870–1871), Paris was besieged by the <a href="/wiki/Prussian_Army" title="Prussian Army">Prussian Army</a>. After months of blockade, hunger, and then bombardment by the Prussians, the city was forced to surrender on 28 January 1871. On 28 March, a revolutionary government called the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Commune" title="Paris Commune">Paris Commune</a> seized power in Paris. The Commune held power for two months, until it was harshly suppressed by the French army during the "<a href="/wiki/Semaine_sanglante" title="Semaine sanglante">Bloody Week</a>" at the end of May 1871.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERougerie2014118_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERougerie2014118-63">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>Late in the 19th century, Paris hosted two major international expositions: the <a href="/wiki/Exposition_Universelle_(1889)" title="Exposition Universelle (1889)">1889 Universal Exposition</a>, was held to mark the centennial of the French Revolution and featured the new Eiffel Tower; and the <a href="/wiki/Exposition_Universelle_(1900)" title="Exposition Universelle (1900)">1900 Universal Exposition</a>, which gave Paris the <a href="/wiki/Pont_Alexandre_III" title="Pont Alexandre III">Pont Alexandre III</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Palais" title="Grand Palais">Grand Palais</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Petit_Palais" title="Petit Palais">Petit Palais</a> and the first <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris Métro</a> line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFraserSpalding2011117_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFraserSpalding2011117-64">[63]</a></sup> Paris became the laboratory of <a href="/wiki/Naturalism_(literature)" title="Naturalism (literature)">Naturalism</a> (<a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Zola" title="Émile Zola">Émile Zola</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">Symbolism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Charles_Baudelaire" title="Charles Baudelaire">Charles Baudelaire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Verlaine" title="Paul Verlaine">Paul Verlaine</a>), and of <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a> in art (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courbet" title="Courbet">Courbet</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manet" title="Manet">Manet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Monet</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Renoir" title="Renoir">Renoir</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996490–491_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996490–491-65">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_and_21st_centuries">20th and 21st centuries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: 20th and 21st centuries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_the_Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Paris in the Belle Époque">Paris in the Belle Époque</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_during_the_First_World_War" title="Paris during the First World War">Paris during the First World War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_between_the_Wars_(1919%E2%80%931939)" title="Paris between the Wars (1919–1939)">Paris between the Wars (1919–1939)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_in_World_War_II" title="Paris in World War II">Paris in World War II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Paris_(1946%E2%80%932000)" title="History of Paris (1946–2000)">History of Paris (1946–2000)</a></div>
<p>By 1901, the population of Paris had grown to about 2,715,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECombeau200361_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECombeau200361-66">[65]</a></sup> At the beginning of the century, artists from around the world including <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Pablo Picasso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amedeo_Modigliani" title="Amedeo Modigliani">Modigliani</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Henri_Matisse" title="Henri Matisse">Henri Matisse</a> made Paris their home. It was the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Fauvism" title="Fauvism">Fauvism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstract art</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996497_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996497-67">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup> and authors such as <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Proust" title="Marcel Proust">Marcel Proust</a> were exploring new approaches to literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996491_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996491-69">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a>, Paris sometimes found itself on the front line; 600 to 1,000 Paris taxis played a small but highly important symbolic role in transporting 6,000 soldiers to the front line at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a>. The city was also bombed by <a href="/wiki/Zeppelin" title="Zeppelin">Zeppelins</a> and shelled by German <a href="/wiki/Paris_Gun" title="Paris Gun">long-range guns</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996750_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996750-70">[69]</a></sup> In the years after the war, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Paris_between_the_Wars_(1919%E2%80%931939)" title="Paris between the Wars (1919–1939)">Les Années Folles</a></i>, Paris continued to be a mecca for writers, musicians and artists from around the world, including <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Hemingway" title="Ernest Hemingway">Ernest Hemingway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Joyce" title="James Joyce">James Joyce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Josephine_Baker" title="Josephine Baker">Josephine Baker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eva_Kotchever" title="Eva Kotchever">Eva Kotchever</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Miller" title="Henry Miller">Henry Miller</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ana%C3%AFs_Nin" title="Anaïs Nin">Anaïs Nin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sidney_Bechet" title="Sidney Bechet">Sidney Bechet</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Allen_Ginsberg" title="Allen Ginsberg">Allen Ginsberg</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wills_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wills-72">[71]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">surrealist</a> <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD" title="Salvador Dalí">Salvador Dalí</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meisler_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Meisler-73">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the years after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">peace conference</a>, the city was also home to growing numbers of students and activists from <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">French colonies</a> and other Asian and African countries, who later became leaders of their countries, such as <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh" title="Ho Chi Minh">Ho Chi Minh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a> and <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9opold_S%C3%A9dar_Senghor" title="Léopold Sédar Senghor">Léopold Sédar Senghor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Liberation_of_Paris,_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1819" data-file-width="2480" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg/220px-The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg/330px-The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg/440px-The_Liberation_of_Paris%2C_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Liberation_of_Paris,_25_-_26_August_1944_HU66477.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>General <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> on the Champs-Élysées celebrating the liberation of Paris, 26 August 1944</div></div></div>
<p>On 14 June 1940, the German army marched into Paris, which had been declared an "<a href="/wiki/Open_city" title="Open city">open city</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012217_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012217-75">[74]</a></sup> On 16–17 July 1942, following German orders, the French police and gendarmes arrested 12,884 Jews, including 4,115 children, and confined them during five days at the <a href="/wiki/Vel%27_d%27Hiv_Roundup" title="Vel' d'Hiv Roundup"><i>Vel d'Hiv</i></a> (<i>Vélodrome d'Hiver</i>), from which they were transported by train to the extermination camp at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">Auschwitz</a>. None of the children came back.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996637_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996637-76">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012218_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012218-77">[76]</a></sup> On 25 August 1944, the city was liberated by the <a href="/wiki/2nd_Armored_Division_(France)" title="2nd Armored Division (France)">French 2nd Armoured Division</a> and the <a href="/wiki/4th_Infantry_Division_(United_States)" title="4th Infantry Division (United States)">4th Infantry Division</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a>. General <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> led a huge and emotional crowd down the Champs Élysées towards Notre Dame de Paris, and made a rousing speech from the <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville,_Paris" title="Hôtel de Ville, Paris">Hôtel de Ville</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996242–243_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996242–243-78">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1950s and the 1960s, Paris became one front of the <a href="/wiki/Algerian_War" title="Algerian War">Algerian War</a> for independence; in August 1961, the pro-independence <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria)" title="National Liberation Front (Algeria)">FLN</a> targeted and killed 11 Paris policemen, leading to the imposition of a curfew on Muslims of Algeria (who, at that time, were French citizens). On 17 October 1961, an unauthorised but peaceful protest demonstration of Algerians against the curfew led to <a href="/wiki/Paris_massacre_of_1961" title="Paris massacre of 1961">violent confrontations</a> between the police and demonstrators, in which at least 40 people were killed, including some thrown into the Seine. The anti-independence <a href="/wiki/Organisation_arm%C3%A9e_secr%C3%A8te" title="Organisation armée secrète">Organisation armée secrète</a> (OAS), for their part, carried out a series of bombings in Paris throughout 1961 and 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996658_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996658-80">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1968, protesting students occupied the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">Sorbonne</a> and put up barricades in the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Quarter,_Paris" title="Latin Quarter, Paris">Latin Quarter</a>. Thousands of Parisian blue-collar workers joined the students, and the movement grew into a two-week general strike. Supporters of the government won the June elections by a large majority. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/May_1968_events_in_France" title="May 1968 events in France">May 1968 events in France</a> resulted in the break-up of the University of Paris into 13 independent campuses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012226_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012226-81">[80]</a></sup> In 1975, the National Assembly changed the status of Paris to that of other French cities and, on 25 March 1977, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Chirac" title="Jacques Chirac">Jacques Chirac</a> became the first elected mayor of Paris since 1793.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996260_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996260-82">[81]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tour_Montparnasse" title="Tour Montparnasse">Tour Maine-Montparnasse</a>, the tallest building in the city at 57 storeys and 210 metres (689 feet) high, was built between 1969 and 1973. It was highly controversial, and it remains the only building in the centre of the city over 32 storeys high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012222_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012222-83">[82]</a></sup> The population of Paris dropped from 2,850,000 in 1954 to 2,152,000 in 1990, as middle-class families moved to the suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECombeau2003107–108_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECombeau2003107–108-84">[83]</a></sup> A suburban railway network, the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_Express_R%C3%A9gional" title="Réseau Express Régional">RER</a> (Réseau Express Régional), was built to complement the Métro; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C3%A9riph%C3%A9rique_(Paris)" title="Périphérique (Paris)">Périphérique</a> expressway encircling the city, was completed in 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBellde-Shalit2011247_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBellde-Shalit2011247-85">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the postwar presidents of the <a href="/wiki/French_Fifth_Republic" title="French Fifth Republic">Fifth Republic</a> wanted to leave their own monuments in Paris; President <a href="/wiki/Georges_Pompidou" title="Georges Pompidou">Georges Pompidou</a> started the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_Georges_Pompidou" title="Centre Georges Pompidou">Centre Georges Pompidou</a> (1977), <a href="/wiki/Val%C3%A9ry_Giscard_d%27Estaing" title="Valéry Giscard d'Estaing">Valéry Giscard d'Estaing</a> began the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a> (1986); President <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">François Mitterrand</a>, in power for 14 years, had the <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_Bastille" title="Opéra Bastille">Opéra Bastille</a> built (1985–1989), the new site of the <i><a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France" title="Bibliothèque nationale de France">Bibliothèque nationale de France</a></i> (1996), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arche_de_la_D%C3%A9fense" title="Arche de la Défense">Arche de la Défense</a> (1985–1989) in <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Louvre_Pyramid" title="Louvre Pyramid">Louvre Pyramid</a> with its underground courtyard (1983–1989); <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Chirac" title="Jacques Chirac">Jacques Chirac</a> (2006), the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_du_Quai_Branly_%E2%80%93_Jacques_Chirac" title="Musée du Quai Branly – Jacques Chirac">Musée du quai Branly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarmant2012226–230_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarmant2012226–230-86">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris,_France,_September_24,_2016_SkySat.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1120" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg/220px-Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg/330px-Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg/440px-Paris%2C_France%2C_September_24%2C_2016_SkySat.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris,_France,_September_24,_2016_SkySat.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Western Paris in 2016, as photographed by a <a href="/wiki/SkySat" title="SkySat">SkySat</a> satellite</div></div></div>
<p>In the early 21st century, the population of Paris began to increase slowly again, as more young people moved into the city. It reached 2.25 million in 2011. In March 2001, <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Delano%C3%AB" title="Bertrand Delanoë">Bertrand Delanoë</a> became the first Socialist Mayor of Paris. In 2007, in an effort to reduce car traffic in the city, he introduced the <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lib%27" title="Vélib'">Vélib'</a>, a system which rents bicycles for the use of local residents and visitors. Bertrand Delanoë also transformed a section of the highway along the Left Bank of the Seine into an urban promenade and park, the <a href="/wiki/Promenade_des_Berges_de_la_Seine" title="Promenade des Berges de la Seine">Promenade des Berges de la Seine</a>, which he inaugurated in June 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2007, President <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Sarkozy" title="Nicolas Sarkozy">Nicolas Sarkozy</a> launched the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Grand Paris</a> project, to integrate Paris more closely with the towns in the region around it. After many modifications, the new area, named the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Metropolis of Grand Paris</a>, with a population of 6.7 million, was created on 1 January 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lichfield_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lichfield-88">[87]</a></sup> In 2011, the City of Paris and the national government approved the plans for the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris_Express" title="Grand Paris Express">Grand Paris Express</a>, totalling 205 kilometres (127 miles) of automated metro lines to connect Paris, the innermost three departments around Paris, airports and <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">high-speed rail (TGV)</a> stations, at an estimated cost of €35 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-metro_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-metro-89">[88]</a></sup> The system is scheduled to be completed by 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique,_18h50,_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="822" data-file-width="2860" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg/350px-Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg/525px-Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg/700px-Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique%2C_18h50%2C_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Place_de_la_R%C3%A9publique,_18h50,_une_foule_silencieuse.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Anti-terrorism demonstration on the Place de la République after the <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Hebdo_shooting" title="Charlie Hebdo shooting"><i>Charlie Hebdo</i> shooting</a>, 11 January 2015</div></div></div>
<p>In January 2015, <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda_in_the_Arabian_Peninsula" title="Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula">Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula</a> claimed <a href="/wiki/January_2015_%C3%8Ele-de-France_attacks" title="January 2015 Île-de-France attacks">attacks</a> across the Paris region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[91]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Republican_marches" title="Republican marches">1.5 million people marched in Paris</a> in a show of solidarity against terrorism and in support of freedom of speech.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup> In November of the same year, <a href="/wiki/November_2015_Paris_attacks" title="November 2015 Paris attacks">terrorist attacks</a>, claimed by ISIL,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup> killed 130 people and injured more than 350.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Location">Location</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Location">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Paris" title="Geography of Paris">Geography of Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4987" data-file-width="5945" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/330px-Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/440px-Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Satellite image of Paris by Sentinel-2</div></div></div>
<p>Paris is located in northern central France, in a north-bending arc of the river <a href="/wiki/Seine" title="Seine">Seine</a> whose crest includes two islands, the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_Saint-Louis" title="Île Saint-Louis">Île Saint-Louis</a> and the larger <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a>, which form the oldest part of the city. The river's mouth on the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> (<i>La Manche</i>) is about 233 mi (375 km) downstream from the city. The city is spread widely on both banks of the river.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-City_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-City-96">[95]</a></sup> Overall, the city is relatively flat, and the lowest point is 35 m (115 ft) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>. Paris has several prominent hills, the highest of which is <a href="/wiki/Montmartre" title="Montmartre">Montmartre</a> at 130 m (427 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004153_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004153-97">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Excluding the outlying parks of <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Boulogne" title="Bois de Boulogne">Bois de Boulogne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Vincennes" title="Bois de Vincennes">Bois de Vincennes</a>, Paris covers an oval measuring about 87 km<sup>2</sup> (34 sq mi) in area, enclosed by the 35 km (22 mi) ring road, the <a href="/wiki/Boulevard_P%C3%A9riph%C3%A9rique" title="Boulevard Périphérique">Boulevard Périphérique</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201069_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201069-98">[97]</a></sup> The city's last major annexation of outlying territories in 1860 not only gave it its modern form but also created the 20 clockwise-spiralling arrondissements (municipal boroughs). From the 1860 area of 78 km<sup>2</sup> (30 sq mi), the city limits were expanded marginally to 86.9 km<sup>2</sup> (33.6 sq mi) in the 1920s. In 1929, the Bois de Boulogne and Bois de Vincennes forest parks were officially annexed to the city, bringing its area to about 105 km<sup>2</sup> (41 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> The metropolitan area of the city is 2,300 km<sup>2</sup> (890 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-City_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-City-96">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Measured from the <a href="/wiki/Kilometre_zero#France" title="Kilometre zero">'point zero'</a> in front of its <a href="/wiki/Notre-Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre-Dame de Paris">Notre-Dame cathedral</a>, Paris by road is 450 kilometres (280 mi) southeast of London, 287 kilometres (178 mi) south of <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">Calais</a>, 305 kilometres (190 mi) southwest of <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, 774 kilometres (481 mi) north of <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>, 385 kilometres (239 mi) northeast of <a href="/wiki/Nantes" title="Nantes">Nantes</a>, and 135 kilometres (84 mi) southeast of <a href="/wiki/Rouen" title="Rouen">Rouen</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Paris" title="Climate of Paris">Climate of Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_(8252181936).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg/220px-Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg/330px-Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg/440px-Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_%288252181936%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_raining_autumn_cityscape_(8252181936).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Autumn in Paris</div></div></div>
<p>Paris has a typical Western European <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Cfb</i>), which is affected by the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Current" title="North Atlantic Current">North Atlantic Current</a>. The overall climate throughout the year is mild and moderately wet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup> Summer days are usually warm and pleasant with average temperatures between 15 and 25 °C (59 and 77 °F), and a fair amount of sunshine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010309_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010309-102">[101]</a></sup> Each year, however, there are a few days when the temperature rises above 32 °C (90 °F). Longer periods of more intense heat sometimes occur, such as the <a href="/wiki/2003_European_heat_wave" title="2003 European heat wave">heat wave of 2003</a> when temperatures exceeded 30 °C (86 °F) for weeks, reached 40 °C (104 °F) on some days and rarely cooled down at night.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein20058_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein20058-103">[102]</a></sup> Spring and autumn have, on average, mild days and fresh nights but are changing and unstable. Surprisingly warm or cool weather occurs frequently in both seasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup> In winter, sunshine is scarce; days are cool, and nights are cold but generally above freezing with low temperatures around 3 °C (37 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup> Light night frosts are however quite common, but the temperature seldom dips below −5 °C (23 °F). Snow falls every year, but rarely stays on the ground. The city sometimes sees light snow or flurries with or without accumulation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris has an average annual precipitation of 641 mm (25.2 in), and experiences light rainfall distributed evenly throughout the year. However, the city is known for intermittent, abrupt, heavy showers. The highest recorded temperature was 42.6 °C (108.7 °F) on 25 July 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup> and the lowest was −23.9 °C (−11.0 °F) on 10 December 1879.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-climate-108">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable centre" style="text-align:right">
<caption class="hidden">Comparison of local Meteorological data with other cities in France<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th scope="col" style="background:#ddffdd">Town
</th>
<th scope="col" style="background-color:#ddffdd" width="100">Sunshine<br/><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" decoding="async" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Weather-clear.svg/20px-Weather-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Weather-clear.svg/30px-Weather-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Weather-clear.svg/40px-Weather-clear.svg.png 2x" width="20"/><br/>(hours/yr)
</th>
<th scope="col" style="background:#ddffdd" width="100">Rain<br/><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" decoding="async" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg/20px-Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg/30px-Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg/40px-Weather-overcast-rare-showers.svg.png 2x" width="20"/><br/>(mm/yr)</th>
