<p><br/>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration">Administration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Administration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administration_of_Paris" title="Administration of Paris">Administration of Paris</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="City_government">City government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: City government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Arrondissements_of_Paris" title="Arrondissements of Paris">Arrondissements of Paris</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Paris" title="List of mayors of Paris">List of mayors of Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_plan_jms.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1334" data-file-width="1840" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Paris_plan_jms.png/220px-Paris_plan_jms.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Paris_plan_jms.png/330px-Paris_plan_jms.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Paris_plan_jms.png/440px-Paris_plan_jms.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_plan_jms.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of the <a href="/wiki/Arrondissements_of_Paris" title="Arrondissements of Paris">arrondissements of Paris</a></div></div></div>
<p>For almost all of its long history, except for a few brief periods, Paris was governed directly by representatives of the king, emperor, or president of France. The city was not granted municipal autonomy by the National Assembly until 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996334_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996334-113">[112]</a></sup> For all but 14 months from 1794 to 1977, Paris was the only French commune without a mayor, and thus had less autonomy than the smallest village. For most of the time from 1800 to 1977 (except briefly in 1848 and 1870–71), it was directly controlled by the departmental prefect (the prefect of the Seine until 1968, and the prefect of Paris from 1968 to 1977).
</p><p>The first modern elected mayor of Paris was <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Chirac" title="Jacques Chirac">Jacques Chirac</a>, elected 20 March 1977, becoming the city's first mayor since 1871 and only the fourth since 1794. The current mayor is <a href="/wiki/Anne_Hidalgo" title="Anne Hidalgo">Anne Hidalgo</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(France)" title="Socialist Party (France)">socialist</a>, first elected <a href="/wiki/2014_Paris_municipal_election" title="2014 Paris municipal election">5 April 2014</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-114">[113]</a></sup> and re-elected <a href="/wiki/2020_Paris_municipal_election" title="2020 Paris municipal election">28 June 2020</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>The mayor of Paris is <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">elected indirectly</a> by Paris voters; the voters of each of the city's 20 arrondissements elect members to the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conseil_de_Paris" title="Conseil de Paris">Conseil de Paris</a></i> (Council of Paris), which subsequently elects the mayor. The council is composed of 163 members, with each arrondissement allocated a number of seats dependent upon its population, from 10 members for each of the least-populated arrondissements (1st through 9th) to 34 members for the most populated (the 15th). The council is elected using <a href="/wiki/Closed_list" title="Closed list">closed list</a> <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Two-round_system" title="Two-round system">two-round system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pariscouncil_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pariscouncil-116">[115]</a></sup> Party lists winning an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Absolute_majority" title="Absolute majority">absolute majority</a> in the first round – or at least a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a> in the second round – automatically win half the seats of an arrondissement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pariscouncil_116-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pariscouncil-116">[115]</a></sup> The remaining half of seats are distributed proportionally to all lists which win at least 5% of the vote using the <a href="/wiki/Highest_averages_method" title="Highest averages method">highest averages method</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup> This ensures that the winning party or coalition always wins a majority of the seats, even if they don't win an absolute majority of the vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pariscouncil_116-2"><a href="#cite_note-Pariscouncil-116">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg/220px-Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg/330px-Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg/440px-Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville_de_Paris_-_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_de_Ville,_Paris" title="Hôtel de Ville, Paris">Hôtel de Ville</a>, or city hall, has been at the same site since 1357.</div></div></div>
<p>Once elected, the council plays a largely passive role in the city government, primarily because it meets only once a month. The council is divided between a coalition of the left of 91 members, including the socialists, communists, greens, and extreme left; and 71 members for the centre-right, plus a few members from smaller parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (August 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Each of Paris's 20 arrondissements has its own town hall and a directly elected council (<i>conseil d'arrondissement</i>), which, in turn, elects an arrondissement mayor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShales200716_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShales200716-119">[118]</a></sup> The council of each arrondissement is composed of members of the Conseil de Paris and also members who serve only on the council of the arrondissement. The number of deputy mayors in each arrondissement varies depending upon its population. There are a total of 20 arrondissement mayors and 120 deputy mayors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996334_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996334-113">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>The budget of the city for 2018 is 9.5 billion Euros, with an expected deficit of 5.5 billion Euros. 7.9 billion Euros are designated for city administration, and 1.7 billion Euros for investment. The number of city employees increased from 40,000 in 2001 to 55,000 in 2018. The largest part of the investment budget is earmarked for public housing (262 million Euros) and for real estate (142 million Euros).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="M.C3.A9tropole_du_Grand_Paris"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Métropole_du_Grand_Paris">Métropole du Grand Paris</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Métropole du Grand Paris">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1882" data-file-width="1534" decoding="async" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg/220px-%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg/330px-%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg/440px-%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C3%89tablissements_publics_territoriaux_du_Grand_Paris_et_trois_d%C3%A9partements.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of the Greater Paris Metropolis (Métropole du Grand Paris) and its governing territories</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Métropole du Grand Paris</a>, or simply <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Grand Paris</a>, formally came into existence on 1 January 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MGP_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-MGP-121">[120]</a></sup> It is an administrative structure for co-operation between the City of Paris and its nearest suburbs. It includes the City of Paris, plus the communes of the three departments of the inner suburbs (<a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Val-de-Marne" title="Val-de-Marne">Val-de-Marne</a>), plus seven communes in the outer suburbs, including <a href="/wiki/Argenteuil" title="Argenteuil">Argenteuil</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Val_d%27Oise" title="Val d'Oise">Val d'Oise</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paray-Vieille-Poste" title="Paray-Vieille-Poste">Paray-Vieille-Poste</a> in <a href="/wiki/Essonne" title="Essonne">Essonne</a>, which were added to include the major airports of Paris. The Metropole covers 814 square kilometres (314 square miles) and has a population of 6.945 million persons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lemoniteur1_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-lemoniteur1-123">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>The new structure is administered by a Metropolitan Council of 210 members, not directly elected, but chosen by the councils of the member Communes. By 2020 its basic competencies will include urban planning, housing and protection of the environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MGP_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-MGP-121">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lemoniteur1_123-1"><a href="#cite_note-lemoniteur1-123">[122]</a></sup> The first president of the metropolitan council, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Ollier" title="Patrick Ollier">Patrick Ollier</a>, a Republican and the mayor of the town of <a href="/wiki/Rueil-Malmaison" title="Rueil-Malmaison">Rueil-Malmaison</a>, was elected on 22 January 2016. Though the Metropole has a population of nearly seven million people and accounts for 25 percent of the GDP of France, it has a very small budget: just 65 million Euros, compared with eight billion Euros for the City of Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_government">Regional government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Regional government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Region" title="Region">Region</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_France" title="Île de France">Île de France</a>, including Paris and its surrounding communities, is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Council_of_%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Regional Council of Île-de-France">Regional Council</a>, which has its headquarters in the 7th arrondissement of Paris. It is composed of 209 members representing the different communes within the region. On 15 December 2015, a list of candidates of the Union of the Right, a coalition of centrist and right-wing parties, led by <a href="/wiki/Val%C3%A9rie_P%C3%A9cresse" title="Valérie Pécresse">Valérie Pécresse</a>, narrowly won the regional election, defeating a coalition of Socialists and ecologists. The Socialists had governed the region for seventeen years. The regional council has 121 members from the Union of the Right, 66 from the Union of the Left and 22 from the extreme right National Front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_government">National government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: National government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_(50610423656).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6057" data-file-width="9086" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg/220px-Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg/330px-Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg/440px-Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_%2850610423656%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Pompeo_Arrives_to_Meet_with_French_Foreign_Minister_Le_Drian_in_Paris_(50610423656).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lys%C3%A9e_Palace" title="Élysée Palace">Élysée Palace</a>, official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President of the French Republic</a></div></div></div>
<p>As the capital of France, Paris is the seat of France's <a href="/wiki/Government_of_France" title="Government of France">national government</a>. For the executive, the two chief officers each have their own official residences, which also serve as their offices. The <a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President of the French Republic</a> resides at the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lys%C3%A9e_Palace" title="Élysée Palace">Élysée Palace</a> in the <a href="/wiki/8th_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="8th arrondissement of Paris">8th arrondissement</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France" title="Prime Minister of France">Prime Minister</a>'s seat is at the <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_Matignon" title="Hôtel Matignon">Hôtel Matignon</a> in the <a href="/wiki/7th_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="7th arrondissement of Paris">7th arrondissement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnappWright200693–94_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnappWright200693–94-128">[127]</a></sup> Government ministries are located in various parts of the city; many are located in the 7th arrondissement, near the Hôtel Matignon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorrus2012288_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorrus2012288-129">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both houses of the <a href="/wiki/French_Parliament" title="French Parliament">French Parliament</a> are located on the Rive Gauche. The upper house, the <a href="/wiki/Senate_(France)" title="Senate (France)">Senate</a>, meets in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palais_du_Luxembourg" title="Palais du Luxembourg">Palais du Luxembourg</a> in the <a href="/wiki/6th_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="6th arrondissement of Paris">6th arrondissement</a>, while the more important lower house, the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(France)" title="National Assembly (France)">National Assembly</a>, meets in the <a href="/wiki/Palais_Bourbon" title="Palais Bourbon">Palais Bourbon</a> in the 7th arrondissement. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_Senate_of_France" title="List of presidents of the Senate of France">President of the Senate</a>, the second-highest public official in France (the President of the Republic being the sole superior), resides in the <a href="/wiki/Petit_Luxembourg" title="Petit Luxembourg">Petit Luxembourg</a>, a smaller palace annexe to the Palais du Luxembourg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="2900" decoding="async" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg/330px-Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg/495px-Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg/660px-Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Conseil_d%27Etat_Paris_WA.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Palais-Royal, residence of the <a href="/wiki/Conseil_d%27%C3%89tat_(France)" title="Conseil d'État (France)">Conseil d'État</a></div></div></div>

<td><a href="/wiki/Mounir_Mahjoubi" title="Mounir Mahjoubi">Mounir Mahjoubi</a>
</td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_R%C3%A9publique_En_Marche!" title="La République En Marche!">La République En Marche!</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background-color: #C9462C">
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Paris%27s_17th_constituency" title="Paris's 17th constituency">Paris's 17th constituency</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Dani%C3%A8le_Obono" title="Danièle Obono">Danièle Obono</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/La_France_Insoumise" title="La France Insoumise">La France Insoumise</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background-color: #0066CC">
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Paris%27s_18th_constituency" title="Paris's 18th constituency">Paris's 18th constituency</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Pierre-Yves_Bournazel" title="Pierre-Yves Bournazel">Pierre-Yves Bournazel</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/The_Republicans_(France)" title="The Republicans (France)">The Republicans</a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>France's highest courts are located in Paris. The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(France)" title="Court of Cassation (France)">Court of Cassation</a>, the highest court in the judicial order, which reviews criminal and civil cases, is located in the <a href="/wiki/Palais_de_Justice,_Paris" title="Palais de Justice, Paris">Palais de Justice</a> on the <i>Île de la Cité</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_State_(France)" title="Council of State (France)">Conseil d'État</a>, which provides legal advice to the executive and acts as the highest court in the administrative order, judging litigation against public bodies, is located in the <a href="/wiki/Palais-Royal" title="Palais-Royal">Palais-Royal</a> in the <a href="/wiki/1st_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="1st arrondissement of Paris">1st arrondissement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_Council_of_France" title="Constitutional Council of France">Constitutional Council</a>, an advisory body with ultimate authority on the constitutionality of laws and government decrees, also meets in the Montpensier wing of the Palais Royal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris and its region host the headquarters of several international organisations including <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Chamber_of_Commerce" title="International Chamber of Commerce">International Chamber of Commerce</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Club" title="Paris Club">Paris Club</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Institute_for_Security_Studies" title="European Union Institute for Security Studies">European Union Institute for Security Studies</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Bureau_of_Weights_and_Measures" title="International Bureau of Weights and Measures">International Bureau of Weights and Measures</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bureau_of_International_Expositions" title="Bureau of International Expositions">International Exhibition Bureau</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_for_Human_Rights" title="International Federation for Human Rights">International Federation for Human Rights</a>.
</p><p>Following the motto "Only Paris is worthy of Rome; only Rome is worthy of Paris";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-partners1_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-partners1-135">[134]</a></sup> the only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Town_twinning" title="Town twinning">sister city</a> of Paris is <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, although Paris has partnership agreements with many other cities around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-partners1_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-partners1-135">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Police_force">Police force</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Police force">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg/220px-Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg/330px-Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg/440px-Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gendarmerie_BMW_R1100RT.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Police (Gendarmerie) motorcyclists in Paris</div></div></div>
<p>The security of Paris is mainly the responsibility of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prefecture_of_Police_of_Paris" title="Prefecture of Police of Paris">Prefecture of Police of Paris</a>, a subdivision of the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Interior_(France)" title="Minister of the Interior (France)">Ministry of the Interior</a>. It supervises the units of the <a href="/wiki/National_Police_(France)" title="National Police (France)">National Police</a> who patrol the city and the three neighbouring departments. It is also responsible for providing emergency services, including the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Fire_Brigade" title="Paris Fire Brigade">Paris Fire Brigade</a>. Its headquarters is on <a href="/wiki/Place_Louis_L%C3%A9pine" title="Place Louis Lépine">Place Louis Lépine</a> on the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Presentation_Generale_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-Presentation_Generale-136">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are 43 800 officers under the prefecture, and a fleet of more than 6,000 vehicles, including police cars, motorcycles, fire trucks, boats and helicopters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Presentation_Generale_136-1"><a href="#cite_note-Presentation_Generale-136">[135]</a></sup> The national police has its own special unit for riot control and crowd control and security of public buildings, called the <a href="/wiki/Compagnies_R%C3%A9publicaines_de_S%C3%A9curit%C3%A9" title="Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité">Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité</a> (CRS), a unit formed in 1944 right after the liberation of France. Vans of CRS agents are frequently seen in the centre of the city when there are demonstrations and public events.
</p><p>The police are supported by the <a href="/wiki/National_Gendarmerie" title="National Gendarmerie">National Gendarmerie</a>, a branch of the <a href="/wiki/French_Armed_Forces" title="French Armed Forces">French Armed Forces</a>, though their police operations now are supervised by the Ministry of the Interior. The traditional <a href="/wiki/Kepi" title="Kepi">kepis</a> of the gendarmes were replaced in 2002 with caps, and the force modernised, though they still wear kepis for ceremonial occasions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Crime in Paris is similar to that in most large cities. Violent crime is relatively rare in the city centre. Political violence is uncommon, though very large demonstrations may occur in Paris and other French cities simultaneously. These demonstrations, usually managed by a strong police presence, can turn confrontational and escalate into violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Cityscape">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1608px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto;direction:rtl"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg" title="‪Panorama of Paris as seen from the Eiffel Tower in a full 360-degree view (river flowing from north-east to south-west, right to left)‬"><img alt="" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="10500" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg/1600px-Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg/2400px-Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg/3200px-Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg 2x" width="1600"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_360_Panorama.jpg" title="File:Tour Eiffel 360 Panorama.jpg"> </a></div>Panorama of Paris as seen from the Eiffel Tower in a full 360-degree view (river flowing from north-east to south-west, right to left)</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanism_and_architecture">Urbanism and architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Urbanism and architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Paris" title="Architecture of Paris">Architecture of Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haussmann%27s_renovation_of_Paris" title="Haussmann's renovation of Paris">Haussmann's renovation of Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religious_buildings_in_Paris" title="Religious buildings in Paris">Religious buildings in Paris</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_the_Paris_region" title="List of tallest buildings and structures in the Paris region">List of tallest buildings and structures in the Paris region</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3382" data-file-width="4357" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg/220px-Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg/330px-Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg/440px-Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Camille_Pissarro_-_Boulevard_Montmartre_-_Eremitage.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Camille_Pissarro" title="Camille Pissarro">Camille Pissarro</a>, <i>Boulevard Montmartre</i>, 1897, <a href="/wiki/Hermitage_Museum" title="Hermitage Museum">Hermitage Museum</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris is one of the few world capitals that has rarely seen destruction by catastrophe or war. For this, even its earliest history is still visible in its streetmap, and centuries of rulers adding their respective architectural marks on the capital has resulted in an accumulated wealth of history-rich monuments and buildings whose beauty played a large part in giving the city the reputation it has today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup> At its origin, before the Middle Ages, the city was composed of several islands and sandbanks in a bend of the <a href="/wiki/Seine" title="Seine">Seine</a>; of those, two remain today: <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_Saint-Louis" title="Île Saint-Louis">Île Saint-Louis</a> and the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a>. A third one is the 1827 artificially created <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_aux_Cygnes" title="Île aux Cygnes">Île aux Cygnes</a>.
</p><p>Modern Paris owes much of its downtown plan and architectural harmony to <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a> and his Prefect of the Seine, <a href="/wiki/Georges-Eug%C3%A8ne_Haussmann" title="Georges-Eugène Haussmann">Baron Haussmann</a>. Between 1853 and 1870 they rebuilt the city centre, created the wide downtown boulevards and squares where the boulevards intersected, imposed standard facades along the boulevards, and required that the facades be built of the distinctive cream-grey "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_stone" title="Paris stone">Paris stone</a>". They also built the major parks around the city centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup> The high residential population of its city centre also makes it much different from most other western major cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBraimohVlek200812_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBraimohVlek200812-141">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night,_Paris_August_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2880" data-file-width="4048" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg/220px-Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg/330px-Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg/440px-Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night%2C_Paris_August_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rue_de_Rivoli_at_night,_Paris_August_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rue_de_Rivoli" title="Rue de Rivoli">Rue de Rivoli</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3013" data-file-width="4515" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg/220px-Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg/330px-Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg/440px-Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_Place_des_Vosges_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Place_des_Vosges" title="Place des Vosges">Place des Vosges</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris's urbanism laws have been under strict control since the early 17th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plan_hauteurs_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-plan_hauteurs-142">[141]</a></sup> particularly where street-front alignment, building height and building distribution is concerned. In recent developments, a 1974–2010 building height limitation of 37 metres (121 ft) was raised to 50 m (160 ft) in central areas and 180 metres (590 ft) in some of Paris's peripheral quarters, yet for some of the city's more central quarters, even older building-height laws still remain in effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plan_hauteurs_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-plan_hauteurs-142">[141]</a></sup> The 210 metres (690 ft) <a href="/wiki/Tour_Montparnasse" title="Tour Montparnasse">Tour Montparnasse</a> was both Paris's and France's tallest building since 1973,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup> but this record has been held by the <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a> quarter <a href="/wiki/Tour_First" title="Tour First">Tour First</a> tower in <a href="/wiki/Courbevoie" title="Courbevoie">Courbevoie</a> since its 2011 construction.
</p><p>Parisian examples of historical architectural styles date back more than a millennium, including the <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a> church of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbey_of_Saint-Germain-des-Pr%C3%A9s" title="Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés">Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés</a> (1014–1163), the early <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gothic_Architecture" title="Gothic Architecture">Gothic Architecture</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Saint-Denis" title="Basilica of Saint-Denis">Basilica of Saint-Denis</a> (1144), the <a href="/wiki/Notre-Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre-Dame de Paris">Notre Dame Cathedral</a> (1163–1345), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flamboyant_Gothic" title="Flamboyant Gothic">Flamboyant Gothic</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Chapelle" title="Saint Chapelle">Saint Chapelle</a> (1239–1248), the <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> churches of <a href="/wiki/Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis" title="Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis">Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis</a> (1627–1641) and <a href="/wiki/Les_Invalides" title="Les Invalides">Les Invalides</a> (1670–1708). The 19th century produced the neoclassical church of <a href="/wiki/La_Madeleine,_Paris" title="La Madeleine, Paris">La Madeleine</a> (1808–1842), the <a href="/wiki/Palais_Garnier" title="Palais Garnier">Palais Garnier</a> serving as an opera house (1875), the neo-Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur,_Paris" title="Sacré-Cœur, Paris">Basilica of Sacré-Cœur</a> (1875–1919), as well as the exuberant <i><a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Belle Époque</a></i> modernism of the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> (1889). Striking examples of 20th-century architecture include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_Georges_Pompidou" title="Centre Georges Pompidou">Centre Georges Pompidou</a> by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Rogers" title="Richard Rogers">Richard Rogers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renzo_Piano" title="Renzo Piano">Renzo Piano</a> (1977), the <a href="/wiki/Cit%C3%A9_des_Sciences_et_de_l%27Industrie" title="Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie">Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie</a> by various architects (1986), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_World_Institute" title="Arab World Institute">Arab World Institute</a> by <a href="/wiki/Jean_Nouvel" title="Jean Nouvel">Jean Nouvel</a> (1987), the <a href="/wiki/Louvre_Pyramid" title="Louvre Pyramid">Louvre Pyramid</a> by <a href="/wiki/I._M._Pei" title="I. M. Pei">I. M. Pei</a> (1989) and the <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_Bastille" title="Opéra Bastille">Opéra Bastille</a> by <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ott" title="Carlos Ott">Carlos Ott</a> (1989). Contemporary architecture includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly_%E2%80%93_Jacques_Chirac" title="Musée du quai Branly – Jacques Chirac">Musée du quai Branly – Jacques Chirac</a> by <a href="/wiki/Jean_Nouvel" title="Jean Nouvel">Jean Nouvel</a> (2006), the contemporary art museum of the <a href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton_Foundation" title="Louis Vuitton Foundation">Louis Vuitton Foundation</a> by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gehry" title="Frank Gehry">Frank Gehry</a> (2014)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup> and the new <a href="/wiki/Tribunal_de_grande_instance_de_Paris" title="Tribunal de grande instance de Paris">Tribunal de grande instance de Paris</a> by <a href="/wiki/Renzo_Piano" title="Renzo Piano">Renzo Piano</a> (2018).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Housing">Housing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Housing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The most expensive residential streets in Paris in 2018 by average price per square metre were <a href="/wiki/Avenue_Montaigne" title="Avenue Montaigne">Avenue Montaigne</a> (8th arrondissement), at 22,372 euros per square metre; <a href="/wiki/Place_Dauphine" title="Place Dauphine">Place Dauphine</a> (1st arrondissement; 20,373 euros) and the Rue de Furstemberg (6th arrondissement) at 18,839 euros per square metre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[144]</a></sup> The total number of residences in the City of Paris in 2011 was 1,356,074, up from a former high of 1,334,815 in 2006. Among these, 1,165,541 (85.9 percent) were main residences, 91,835 (6.8 percent) were secondary residences, and the remaining 7.3 percent were empty (down from 9.2 percent in 2006).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-insee_logement_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-insee_logement-146">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sixty-two percent of its buildings date from 1949 and before, 20 percent were built between 1949 and 1974, and only 18 percent of the buildings remaining were built after that date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-notaires_idf_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-notaires_idf-147">[146]</a></sup> Two-thirds of the city's 1.3 million residences are studio and two-room apartments. Paris averages 1.9 people per residence, a number that has remained constant since the 1980s, but it is much less than Île-de-France's 2.33 person-per-residence average. Only 33 percent of principal residence Parisians own their habitation (against 47 percent for the entire Île-de-France): the major part of the city's population is a rent-paying one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-notaires_idf_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-notaires_idf-147">[146]</a></sup> Social or public housing represented 19.9 percent of the city's total residences in 2017. Its distribution varies widely throughout the city, from 2.6 percent of the housing in the wealthy 7th arrondissement, to 24 percent in the 20th arrondissement, 26 percent in the 14th arrondissement and 39.9 percent in the 19th arrondissement, on the poorer southwest and northern edges of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the night of 8–9 February 2019, during a period of cold weather, a Paris NGO conducted its annual citywide count of homeless persons. They counted 3,641 homeless persons in Paris, of whom twelve percent were women. More than half had been homeless for more than a year. 2,885 were living in the streets or parks, 298 in train and metro stations, and 756 in other forms of temporary shelter. This was an increase of 588 persons since 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Paris_and_its_suburbs">Paris and its suburbs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Paris and its suburbs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg/220px-Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg/330px-Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg/440px-Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_SPOT_1017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Paris and its suburbs, as seen from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spot_Satellite" title="Spot Satellite">Spot Satellite</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg/220px-West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg/330px-West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg/440px-West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_of_Paris_seen_from_Tour_Montparnasse_-_2019-09-18.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>West of Paris seen from <a href="/wiki/Tour_Montparnasse" title="Tour Montparnasse">Tour Montparnasse</a> in 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Aside from the 20th-century addition of the Bois de Boulogne, the Bois de Vincennes and the Paris heliport, Paris's administrative limits have remained unchanged since 1860. A greater administrative <a href="/wiki/Seine_(department)" title="Seine (department)">Seine</a> department had been governing Paris and its suburbs since its creation in 1790, but the rising suburban population had made it difficult to maintain as a unique entity. To address this problem, the parent "District de la région parisienne" ('district of the Paris region') was reorganised into several new departments from 1968: Paris became a department in itself, and the administration of its suburbs was divided between the three new departments surrounding it. The district of the Paris region was renamed "<a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Île-de-France</a>" in 1977, but this abbreviated "Paris region" name is still commonly used today to describe the Île-de-France, and as a vague reference to the entire Paris agglomeration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup> Long-intended measures to unite Paris with its suburbs began on 1 January 2016, when the Métropole du <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Grand Paris</a> came into existence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MGP_121-2"><a href="#cite_note-MGP-121">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris's disconnect with its suburbs, its lack of suburban transportation, in particular, became all too apparent with the Paris agglomeration's growth. <a href="/wiki/Paul_Delouvrier" title="Paul Delouvrier">Paul Delouvrier</a> promised to resolve the Paris-suburbs <i>mésentente</i> when he became head of the Paris region in 1961:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMasson1984536_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMasson1984536-151">[150]</a></sup> two of his most ambitious projects for the Region were the construction of five suburban "villes nouvelles" ("new cities")<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYarri2008407_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYarri2008407-152">[151]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_Express_R%C3%A9gional" title="Réseau Express Régional">RER</a> commuter train network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGordon200646–47_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGordon200646–47-153">[152]</a></sup> Many other suburban residential districts (<i>grands ensembles</i>) were built between the 1960s and 1970s to provide a low-cost solution for a rapidly expanding population:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECastells198375_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECastells198375-154">[153]</a></sup> These districts were socially mixed at first,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETomasBlancBonillaIERP2003237_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETomasBlancBonillaIERP2003237-155">[154]</a></sup> but few residents actually owned their homes (the growing economy made these accessible to the middle classes only from the 1970s).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-villes_nouvelles_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-villes_nouvelles-156">[155]</a></sup> Their poor construction quality and their haphazard insertion into existing urban growth contributed to their desertion by those able to move elsewhere and their repopulation by those with more limited possibilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-villes_nouvelles_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-villes_nouvelles-156">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>These areas, <i>quartiers sensibles</i> ("sensitive quarters"), are in northern and eastern Paris, namely around its <a href="/wiki/Goutte_d%27Or" title="Goutte d'Or">Goutte d'Or</a> and <a href="/wiki/Belleville,_Paris" title="Belleville, Paris">Belleville</a> neighbourhoods. To the north of the city, they are grouped mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_(France)" title="Department (France)">department</a>, and to a lesser extreme to the east in the <a href="/wiki/Val-d%27Oise" title="Val-d'Oise">Val-d'Oise</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_(France)" title="Department (France)">department</a>. Other difficult areas are located in the <a href="/wiki/Seine" title="Seine">Seine</a> valley, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89vry_(Essonne)" title="Évry (Essonne)">Évry</a> et <a href="/wiki/Corbeil-Essonnes" title="Corbeil-Essonnes">Corbeil-Essonnes</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Essonne_(d%C3%A9partement)" title="Essonne (département)">Essonne</a>), in <a href="/wiki/Les_Mureaux" title="Les Mureaux">Mureaux</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mantes-la-Jolie" title="Mantes-la-Jolie">Mantes-la-Jolie</a> (<a href="/wiki/Yvelines" title="Yvelines">Yvelines</a>), and scattered among social housing districts created by Delouvrier's 1961 "ville nouvelle" political initiative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Paris agglomeration's <a href="/wiki/Urban_sociology" title="Urban sociology">urban sociology</a> is basically that of 19th-century Paris: its fortuned classes are situated in its west and southwest, and its middle-to-lower classes are in its north and east. The remaining areas are mostly middle-class citizenry dotted with islands of fortuned populations located there due to reasons of historical importance, namely <a href="/wiki/Saint-Maur-des-Foss%C3%A9s" title="Saint-Maur-des-Fossés">Saint-Maur-des-Fossés</a> to the east and <a href="/wiki/Enghien-les-Bains" title="Enghien-les-Bains">Enghien-les-Bains</a> to the north of Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#ffffff;">
<td><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Cameroon" title="Cameroon"><img alt="Cameroon" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Flag_of_Cameroon.svg/23px-Flag_of_Cameroon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Flag_of_Cameroon.svg/35px-Flag_of_Cameroon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Flag_of_Cameroon.svg/45px-Flag_of_Cameroon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Cameroonians_in_France" title="Cameroonians in France">Cameroon</a></td>
<td style="text-align:center;">45,250

<tr style="background:#eeeeee;">
<td><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations"><img alt="United Nations" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_United_Nations.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> Other countries and territories</td>
<td style="text-align:center;">855,046
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The official estimated population of the City of Paris was 2,165,423 on 1 January 2022, according to the <a href="/wiki/Institut_national_de_la_statistique_et_des_%C3%A9tudes_%C3%A9conomiques" title="Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques">INSEE</a>, the official French statistical agency. This was a decline of 11,000 from January 2021, and a drop of 65,000 over six years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> Despite the drop, Paris remains the most densely-populated city in Europe, with 252 residents per hectare, not counting parks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Le_Monde,_22_January_2019_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-Le_Monde,_22_January_2019-162">[161]</a></sup> This drop was attributed partly to a lower birth rate, the departure of middle-class residents and the possible loss of housing in the city due to short-term rentals for tourism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-163">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris is the fourth largest municipality in the European Union, following <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> places Paris (6.5 million people) behind London (8 million) and ahead of Berlin (3.5 million), based on the 2012 populations of what Eurostat calls "urban audit core cities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_Historical_Population_(1801-2008).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="1173" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png/250px-Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png/375px-Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png/500px-Paris_Historical_Population_%281801-2008%29.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_Historical_Population_(1801-2008).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>City proper, urban area, and metropolitan area population from 1800 to 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The population of Paris today is lower than its historical peak of 2.9 million in 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup> The principal reasons were a significant decline in household size, and a dramatic migration of residents to the suburbs between 1962 and 1975. Factors in the migration included <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/De-industrialisation" title="De-industrialisation">de-industrialisation</a>, high rent, the <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a> of many inner quarters, the transformation of living space into offices, and greater affluence among working families. The city's population loss came to a temporary halt at the beginning of the 21st century; the population increased from 2,125,246 in 1999 to 2,240,621 in 2012, before declining again slightly in 2017, 2018, and again in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pophis_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-pophis-167">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris is the core of a built-up area that extends well beyond its limits: commonly referred to as the <i>agglomération Parisienne</i>, and statistically as a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unit%C3%A9_urbaine" title="Unité urbaine">unité urbaine</a></i> (a measure of <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban area</a>), the Paris agglomeration's population of 10,785,092 in 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop_UU_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop_UU-168">[167]</a></sup> made it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_European_Union" title="List of urban areas in the European Union">largest urban area in the European Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urbaneurope_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-urbaneurope-169">[168]</a></sup> City-influenced commuter activity reaches well beyond even this in a statistical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Metropolitan_Area" title="Paris Metropolitan Area"><i>aire d'attraction</i> de Paris</a> ("functional area", a statistical method comparable to a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FU_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FU-170">[169]</a></sup>), that had a population of 13,024,518 in 2017,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop_AU_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop_AU-171">[170]</a></sup> 19.6% of the population of France,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[171]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe" title="List of metropolitan areas in Europe">largest</a> metropolitan area in the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urbaneurope_169-1"><a href="#cite_note-urbaneurope-169">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, the EU statistical agency, in 2012 the Commune of Paris was the most densely populated city in the European Union, with 21,616 people per square kilometre within the city limits (the NUTS-3 statistical area), ahead of Inner London West, which had 10,374 people per square kilometre. According to the same census, three departments bordering Paris, <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Val-de-Marne" title="Val-de-Marne">Val-de-Marne</a>, had population densities of over 10,000 people per square kilometre, ranking among the 10 most densely populated areas of the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[172]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Old data, 2012 does not match with report date (March 2014). Current report could be different. (June 2019)">verification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">Migration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Migration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>According to the 2012 French census, 586,163 residents of the City of Paris, or 26.2 percent, and 2,782,834 residents of the Paris Region (Île-de-France), or 23.4 percent, were born outside of <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">metropolitan France</a> (the last figure up from 22.4% at the 2007 census).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> 26,700 of these in the City of Paris and 210,159 in the Paris Region were people born in <a href="/wiki/Overseas_France" title="Overseas France">Overseas France</a> (more than two-thirds of whom in the <a href="/wiki/French_West_Indies" title="French West Indies">French West Indies</a>) and are therefore not counted as immigrants since they were legally French citizens at birth.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>A further 103,648 in the City of Paris and in 412,114 in the Paris Region were born in foreign countries with French citizenship at birth.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> This concerns in particular the many <a href="/wiki/Pied-Noir" title="Pied-Noir">Christians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maghrebi_Jews" title="Maghrebi Jews">Jews</a> from North Africa who moved to France and Paris after the times of independence and are not counted as immigrants due to their being born French citizens. The remaining group, people born in foreign countries with no French citizenship at birth, are those defined as immigrants under French law. According to the 2012 census, 135,853 residents of the City of Paris were immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, 112,369 were immigrants from the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>, 70,852 from <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, 5,059 from <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, 91,297 from <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> (outside Turkey), 38,858 from the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, and 1,365 from the <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">South Pacific</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup> Note that the immigrants from the Americas and the South Pacific in Paris are vastly outnumbered by migrants from French overseas regions and territories located in these regions of the world.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In the Paris Region, 590,504 residents were immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, 627,078 were immigrants from the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>, 435,339 from <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, 69,338 from <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, 322,330 from <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> (outside Turkey), 113,363 from the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, and 2,261 from the <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">South Pacific</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> These last two groups of immigrants are again vastly outnumbered by migrants from French overseas regions and territories located in the Americas and the South Pacific.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="It is unclear how this paragraph is different from the previous one. (February 2019)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In 2012, there were 8,810 British citizens and 10,019 United States citizens living in the City of Paris (Ville de Paris) and 20,466 British citizens and 16,408 United States citizens living in the entire Paris Region (<a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Île-de-France</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Religious_buildings_in_Paris" title="Religious buildings in Paris">Religious buildings in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1827" data-file-width="2832" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg/220px-Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg/330px-Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg/440px-Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basilique_du_Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur_de_Montmartre_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur,_Paris" title="Sacré-Cœur, Paris">Sacré-Cœur</a> in <a href="/wiki/Montmartre" title="Montmartre">Montmartre</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres,_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2667" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg/220px-Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg/330px-Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg/440px-Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres%2C_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saint_Gervais_church_from_the_rue_des_Barres,_Paris_26_September_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St-Gervais-et-St-Protais" title="St-Gervais-et-St-Protais">St-Gervais-et-St-Protais</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Marais" title="The Marais">Le Marais</a></div></div></div>
<p>At the beginning of the twentieth century, Paris was the largest <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a> city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup> French census data does not contain information about religious affiliation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup> According to a 2011 survey by the <a href="/wiki/Institut_fran%C3%A7ais_d%27opinion_publique" title="Institut français d'opinion publique">Institut français d'opinion publique</a> (IFOP), a French public opinion research organisation, 61 percent of residents of the Paris Region (Île-de-France) identified themselves as <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a>. In the same survey, 7 percent of residents identified themselves as Muslims, 4 percent as Protestants, 2 percent as Jewish and 25 percent as without religion.
</p><p>According to the INSEE, between 4 and 5 million French residents were born or had at least one parent born in a predominantly Muslim country, particularly <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>. An IFOP survey in 2008 reported that, of immigrants from these predominantly Muslim countries, 25 percent went to the mosque regularly; 41 percent practised the religion, and 34 percent were believers but did not practice the religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup> In 2012 and 2013, it was estimated that there were almost 500,000 Muslims in the City of Paris, 1.5 million Muslims in the Île-de-France region and 4 to 5 million Muslims in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Jewish population of the Paris Region was estimated in 2014 to be 282,000, the largest concentration of Jews in the world outside of <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_organisations">International organisations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: International organisations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization</a> (UNESCO) has had its headquarters in Paris since November 1958. Paris is also the home of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup> Paris hosts the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Securities_and_Markets_Authority" title="European Securities and Markets Authority">European Securities and Markets Authority</a> and, since 2019, the <a href="/wiki/European_Banking_Authority" title="European Banking Authority">European Banking Authority</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Paris" title="Economy of Paris">Economy of Paris</a></div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1288px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg" title="La Défense, the largest dedicated business district in Europe"><img alt="" data-file-height="2206" data-file-width="13187" decoding="async" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg/1280px-Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg/1920px-Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg/2560px-Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg 2x" width="1280"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_La_D%C3%A9fense.jpg" title="File:Panorama La Défense.jpg"> </a></div><a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a>, the largest dedicated business district in Europe<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France.fr_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-France.fr-186">[185]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<td colspan="3">Source: <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a> (2021)
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3,_Paris_May_2014.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2827" data-file-width="3990" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg/280px-Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg/420px-Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg/560px-Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3%2C_Paris_May_2014.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_from_the_Tour_Montparnasse_3,_Paris_May_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> and the <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a> district</div></div></div>
<p>The economy of the City of Paris is based largely on services and commerce; of the 390,480 enterprises in the city, 80.6 percent are engaged in commerce, transportation, and diverse services, 6.5 percent in construction, and just 3.8 percent in industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup> The story is similar in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Region" title="Paris Region">Paris Region</a> (Île-de-France): 76.7 percent of enterprises are engaged in commerce and services, and 3.4 percent in industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the 2012 census, 59.5% of jobs in the Paris Region were in market services (12.0% in wholesale and retail trade, 9.7% in professional, scientific, and technical services, 6.5% in information and communication, 6.5% in transportation and warehousing, 5.9% in finance and insurance, 5.8% in administrative and support services, 4.6% in accommodation and food services, and 8.5% in various other market services), 26.9% in non-market services (10.4% in human health and social work activities, 9.6% in public administration and defence, and 6.9% in education), 8.2% in manufacturing and utilities (6.6% in manufacturing and 1.5% in utilities), 5.2% in construction, and 0.2% in agriculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Paris Region had 5.4 million salaried employees in 2010, of whom 2.2 million were concentrated in 39 <i>pôles d'emplois</i> or business districts. The largest of these, in terms of number of employees, is known in French as the QCA, or <i>quartier central des affaires</i>; it is in the western part of the City of Paris, in the 2nd, 8th, 9th, 16th, and 18th arrondissements. In 2010, it was the workplace of 500,000 salaried employees, about 30 percent of the salaried employees in Paris and 10 percent of those in the Île-de-France. The largest sectors of activity in the central business district were finance and insurance (16 percent of employees in the district) and business services (15 percent). The district also includes a large concentration of department stores, shopping areas, hotels and restaurants, as well a government offices and ministries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE-191">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>The second-largest business district in terms of employment is <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a>, just west of the city, where many companies installed their offices in the 1990s. In 2010, it was the workplace of 144,600 employees, of whom 38 percent worked in finance and insurance, 16 percent in business support services. Two other important districts, <a href="/wiki/Neuilly-sur-Seine" title="Neuilly-sur-Seine">Neuilly-sur-Seine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Levallois-Perret" title="Levallois-Perret">Levallois-Perret</a>, are extensions of the Paris business district and of La Défense. Another district, including <a href="/wiki/Boulogne-Billancourt" title="Boulogne-Billancourt">Boulogne-Billancourt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Issy-les-Moulineaux" title="Issy-les-Moulineaux">Issy-les-Moulineaux</a> and the southern part of the 15th arrondissement, is a centre of activity for the media and information technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE-191">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>The top French companies listed in the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a> for 2021 all have their headquarters in the Paris Region; six in the central business district of the City of Paris; and four close to the city in the <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a> Department, three in <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a> and one in <a href="/wiki/Boulogne-Billancourt" title="Boulogne-Billancourt">Boulogne-Billancourt</a>.
