Some companies, like <a href="/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale" title="Société Générale">Société Générale</a>, have offices in both Paris and La Défense.
</p><p>The Paris Region is France's leading region for economic activity, with a <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> of <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">€</a>681 billion (~US$850 billion) and €56,000 (~US$70,000) per capita.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Euro-PR_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Euro-PR-192">[191]</a></sup> In 2011, its GDP ranked second among the regions of Europe and its per-capita GDP was the 4th highest in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinsey_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-McKinsey-194">[193]</a></sup> While the Paris region's population accounted for 18.8 percent of metropolitan France in 2011,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> the Paris region's GDP accounted for 30 percent of metropolitan France's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paris_GDP_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Paris_GDP-196">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Paris Region economy has gradually shifted from industry to high-value-added service industries (<a href="/wiki/Financial_services" title="Financial services">finance</a>, IT services) and high-tech manufacturing (electronics, optics, aerospace, etc.).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> The Paris region's most intense economic activity through the central <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a> department and suburban La Défense business district places Paris's economic centre to the west of the city, in a triangle between the <a href="/wiki/Palais_Garnier" title="Palais Garnier"><i>Opéra Garnier</i></a>, <i>La Défense</i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Val_de_Seine" title="Val de Seine">Val de Seine</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> While the Paris economy is dominated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Service_Sector" title="Service Sector">services</a>, and employment in manufacturing sector has declined sharply, the region remains an important manufacturing centre, particularly for aeronautics, automobiles, and "eco" industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-2"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2017 worldwide cost of living survey by the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>, based on a survey made in September 2016, Paris ranked as the seventh most expensive city in the world, and the second most expensive in Europe, after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zurich" title="Zurich">Zurich</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, Paris was the most expensive city in the world with <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Station_F" title="Station F">Station F</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Business_incubator" title="Business incubator">business incubator</a> for startups, located in <a href="/wiki/13th_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="13th arrondissement of Paris">13th arrondissement of Paris</a>. Noted as the world's largest startup facility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Employment">Employment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Employment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4048" data-file-width="4538" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png/220px-Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png/330px-Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png/440px-Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_emploi_2015_jms.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Employment by economic sector in the Paris area (petite couronne), with population and unemployment figures (2015)</div></div></div>
<p>According to 2015 INSEE figures, 68.3 percent of employees in the City of Paris work in commerce, transportation, and services; 24.5 percent in public administration, health and social services; 4.1 percent in industry, and 0.1 percent in agriculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ParisAU_workforce_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-ParisAU_workforce-201">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of Paris's salaried employees fill 370,000 businesses services jobs, concentrated in the north-western 8th, 16th and 17th arrondissements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlapageINSEE_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-AlapageINSEE-202">[201]</a></sup> Paris's financial service companies are concentrated in the central-western 8th and 9th arrondissement banking and insurance district.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlapageINSEE_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-AlapageINSEE-202">[201]</a></sup> Paris's department store district in the 1st, 6th, 8th and 9th arrondissements employ ten percent of mostly female Paris workers, with 100,000 of these registered in the retail trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlapageINSEE_202-2"><a href="#cite_note-AlapageINSEE-202">[201]</a></sup> Fourteen percent of Parisians work in hotels and restaurants and other services to individuals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlapageINSEE_202-3"><a href="#cite_note-AlapageINSEE-202">[201]</a></sup> Nineteen percent of Paris employees work for the State in either administration or education. The majority of Paris's healthcare and social workers work at the hospitals and social housing concentrated in the peripheral 13th, 14th, 18th, 19th and 20th arrondissements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlapageINSEE_202-4"><a href="#cite_note-AlapageINSEE-202">[201]</a></sup> Outside Paris, the western Hauts-de-Seine department <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a> district specialising in finance, insurance and scientific research district, employs 144,600,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-3"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> and the north-eastern Seine-Saint-Denis audiovisual sector has 200 media firms and 10 major film studios.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-4"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris's manufacturing is mostly focused in its suburbs, and the city itself has only around 75,000 manufacturing workers, most of which are in the textile, clothing, leather goods, and shoe trades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-5"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> Paris region manufacturing specialises in transportation, mainly automobiles, aircraft and trains, but this is in a sharp decline: Paris proper manufacturing jobs dropped by 64 percent between 1990 and 2010, and the Paris region lost 48 percent during the same period. Most of this is due to companies relocating outside the Paris region. The Paris region's 800 aerospace companies employed 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-6"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> Four hundred automobile industry companies employ another 100,000 workers: many of these are centred in the <a href="/wiki/Yvelines" title="Yvelines">Yvelines</a> department around the Renault and PSA-Citroën plants (this department alone employs 33,000),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-7"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> but the industry as a whole suffered a major loss with the 2014 closing of a major <a href="/wiki/Aulnay-sous-Bois" title="Aulnay-sous-Bois">Aulnay-sous-Bois</a> Citroën assembly plant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-8"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>The southern <a href="/wiki/Essonne" title="Essonne">Essonne</a> department specialises in science and technology,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-9"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> and the south-eastern <a href="/wiki/Val-de-Marne" title="Val-de-Marne">Val-de-Marne</a>, with its wholesale <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/March%C3%A9_international_de_Rungis" title="Marché international de Rungis">Rungis food market</a>, specialises in food processing and beverages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-10"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> The Paris region's manufacturing decline is quickly being replaced by eco-industries: these employ about 100,000 workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE_201210_197-11"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE_201210-197">[196]</a></sup> In 2011, while only 56,927 construction workers worked in Paris itself,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup> its metropolitan area employed 246,639,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ParisAU_workforce_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-ParisAU_workforce-201">[200]</a></sup> in an activity centred largely on the <a href="/wiki/Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> (41,378)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93_workforce_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-93_workforce-204">[203]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a> (37,303)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92_workforce_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-92_workforce-205">[204]</a></sup> departments and the new business-park centres appearing there.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Unemployment">Unemployment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Unemployment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The unemployment rate in Paris in the 4th trimester of 2021 was six percent, compared with 7.2 percent in the whole Ile-de-France, and 7.4 percent in the whole of France. This was the lowest rate in thirteen years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Incomes">Incomes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Incomes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_(2018)_named.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg/220px-Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg/330px-Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg/440px-Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_%282018%29_named.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Median_income_of_Paris_and_inner_ring_(2018)_named.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Median income in Paris and its nearest departments in 2018 (high income in red, low income in yellow)</div></div></div>
<p>The average net household income (after social, pension and health insurance contributions) in Paris was €36,085 for 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> It ranged from €22,095 in the 19th arrondissement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup> to €82,449 in the 7th arrondissement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup> The median <a href="/wiki/Taxable_income" title="Taxable income">taxable income</a> for 2011 was around €25,000 in Paris and €22,200 for <i>Île-de-France</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup> Generally speaking, incomes are higher in the Western part of the city and in the western suburbs than in the northern and eastern parts of the urban area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wealth_distribution_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-wealth_distribution-212">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Paris has some of the richest neighbourhoods in France, it also has some of the poorest, mostly on the eastern side of the city. In 2012, 14 percent of households in the city earned less than €977 per month, the official <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poverty_line" title="Poverty line">poverty line</a>. Twenty-five percent of residents in the 19th arrondissement lived below the poverty line; 24 percent in the 18th, 22 percent in the 20th and 18 percent in the 10th. In the city's wealthiest neighbourhood, the 7th arrondissement, 7 percent lived below the poverty line; 8 percent in the 6th arrondissement; and 9 percent in the 16th arrondissement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Paris" title="Tourism in Paris">Tourism in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_!_(4787187477).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg/170px-Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg/255px-Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg/340px-Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_%21_%284787187477%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Visiter_le_Louvre_en_%C3%A9t%C3%A9_!_(4787187477).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tourists from around the world make the <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a> the most-visited art museum in the world.</div></div></div>
<p>Tourism recovered in the Paris region in 2021, increasing to 22.6 million visitors, thirty percent more than in 2020, but still well below 2019 levels. The number of visitors from the United States increased by 237 percent over 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris" title="Grand Paris">Greater Paris</a>, comprising Paris and its three surrounding departments, received 38 million visitors in 2019, a record, measured by hotel arrivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KeyFigures_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-KeyFigures-215">[214]</a></sup> These included 12.2 million French visitors. Of foreign visitors, the greatest number came from the United States (2.6 million), United Kingdom (1.2 million), Germany (981 thousand) and China (711 thousand).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KeyFigures_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-KeyFigures-215">[214]</a></sup> However, tourism to Paris and its region fell to 17.5 million in 2020 due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, with a 78 percent drop in foreign tourists measured by hotel stays, and a drop of 56 percent in French guests, for an overall drop of 68 percent. This caused a drop 15 billion Euros in hotel receipts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, measured by the Euromonitor Global Cities Destination Index, Paris was the second-busiest airline destination in the world, with 19.10 million visitors, behind Bangkok (22.78 million) but ahead of London (19.09 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> According to the Paris Convention and Visitors Bureau, 393,008 workers in Greater Paris, or 12.4% of the total workforce, are engaged in tourism-related sectors such as hotels, catering, transport and leisure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIP2016_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-TIP2016-218">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monuments_and_attractions">Monuments and attractions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Monuments and attractions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Landmarks_in_Paris" title="Landmarks in Paris">Landmarks in Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historical_quarters_of_Paris" title="Historical quarters of Paris">Historical quarters of Paris</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Paris" title="List of tourist attractions in Paris">List of tourist attractions in Paris</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_most_visited_museums" title="List of most visited museums">List of most visited museums</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PassageJouffroy1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1620" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/PassageJouffroy1.jpg/170px-PassageJouffroy1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/PassageJouffroy1.jpg/255px-PassageJouffroy1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/PassageJouffroy1.jpg/340px-PassageJouffroy1.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PassageJouffroy1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Passage_Jouffroy" title="Passage Jouffroy">Passage Jouffroy</a>, one of Paris's <a href="/wiki/Covered_passages_of_Paris" title="Covered passages of Paris">covered passages</a></div></div></div>
<p>The city's top cultural attraction in 2019 was the <a href="/wiki/Sacr%C3%A9-C%C5%93ur,_Paris" title="Sacré-Cœur, Paris">Basilica of Sacré-Cœur</a> (11 million visitors), followed by the <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a> (9.6 million visitors); the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> (6.1 million visitors); the <a href="/wiki/Centre_Pompidou" title="Centre Pompidou">Centre Pompidou</a> (3.5 million visitors); and the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a> (3.3 million visitors).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KeyFigures_215-2"><a href="#cite_note-KeyFigures-215">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>The centre of Paris contains the most visited monuments in the city, including the Notre Dame Cathedral (now closed for restoration) and the Louvre as well as the <a href="/wiki/Sainte-Chapelle" title="Sainte-Chapelle">Sainte-Chapelle</a>; <a href="/wiki/Les_Invalides" title="Les Invalides">Les Invalides</a>, where the tomb of Napoleon is located, and the Eiffel Tower are located on the Left Bank south-west of the centre. The <a href="/wiki/Panth%C3%A9on" title="Panthéon">Panthéon</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Catacombs_of_Paris" title="Catacombs of Paris">Catacombs of Paris</a> are also located on the Left Bank of the Seine. The banks of the Seine from the <a href="/wiki/Pont_de_Sully" title="Pont de Sully">Pont de Sully</a> west to the <a href="/wiki/Pont_d%27I%C3%A9na" title="Pont d'Iéna">Pont d'Iéna</a> have been listed as a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> since 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unescowh_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-unescowh-219">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Champs-Elys%C3%A9es,_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="528" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg/170px-Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg/255px-Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg/340px-Champs-Elys%C3%A9es%2C_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Champs-Elys%C3%A9es,_vue_de_la_Concorde_%C3%A0_l%27Etoile.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Axe_historique" title="Axe historique">Axe historique</a></i>, pictured here from <a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Concorde" title="Place de la Concorde">Concorde</a> to <a href="/wiki/Grande_Arche" title="Grande Arche">Grande Arche</a> of <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a></div></div></div>
<p>Other landmarks are laid out east to west along the historical axis of Paris, which runs from the Louvre through the <a href="/wiki/Tuileries_Garden" title="Tuileries Garden">Tuileries Garden</a>, the Luxor Column in the <a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Concorde" title="Place de la Concorde">Place de la Concorde</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a>, to the <a href="/wiki/Grande_Arche" title="Grande Arche">Grande Arche</a> of La Défense.
Several other much-visited landmarks are located in the suburbs of the city; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basilica_of_St_Denis" title="Basilica of St Denis">Basilica of St Denis</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a>, is the birthplace of the Gothic style of architecture and the royal necropolis of French kings and queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> The Paris region hosts three other UNESCO Heritage sites: the Palace of Versailles in the west,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Fontainebleau" title="Palace of Fontainebleau">Palace of Fontainebleau</a> in the south,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup> and the medieval fairs site of <a href="/wiki/Provins" title="Provins">Provins</a> in the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup> In the Paris region, <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Marne-la-Vall%C3%A9e" title="Marne-la-Vallée">Marne-la-Vallée</a>, 32 kilometres (20 miles) east of the centre of Paris, received 9.66 million visitors in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hotels">Hotels</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Hotels">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2019, Greater Paris had 2,056 hotels, including 94 five-star hotels, with a total of 121,646 rooms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KeyFigures_215-3"><a href="#cite_note-KeyFigures-215">[214]</a></sup> Paris has long been famous for its grand hotels. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hotel_Meurice" title="Hotel Meurice">Hotel Meurice</a>, opened for British travellers in 1817, was one of the first luxury hotels in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996938_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996938-225">[224]</a></sup> The arrival of the railways and the <a href="/wiki/Exposition_Universelle_(1855)" title="Exposition Universelle (1855)">Paris Exposition of 1855</a> brought the first flood of tourists and the first modern grand hotels; the Hôtel du Louvre (now an antiques marketplace) in 1855; the Grand Hotel (now the <a href="/wiki/InterContinental_Paris_Le_Grand_Hotel" title="InterContinental Paris Le Grand Hotel">InterContinental Paris Le Grand Hotel</a>) in 1862; and the Hôtel Continental in 1878. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hotel_Ritz_Paris" title="Hotel Ritz Paris">Hôtel Ritz</a> on Place Vendôme opened in 1898, followed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_Crillon" title="Hôtel Crillon">Hôtel Crillon</a> in an 18th-century building on the Place de la Concorde in 1909; the <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_Le_Bristol_Paris" title="Hôtel Le Bristol Paris">Hotel Bristol</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Rue_du_Faubourg_Saint-Honor%C3%A9" title="Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré">Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré</a> in 1925; and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hotel_George_V" title="Hotel George V">Hotel George V</a> in 1928.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996937–938_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996937–938-226">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to hotels, in 2019 Greater Paris had 60,000 homes registered with <a href="/wiki/Airbnb" title="Airbnb">Airbnb</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KeyFigures_215-4"><a href="#cite_note-KeyFigures-215">[214]</a></sup> Under French law, renters of these units must pay the Paris tourism tax. The company paid the city government 7.3 million euros in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Painting_and_sculpture">Painting and sculpture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Painting and sculpture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_in_Paris" title="Art in Paris">Art in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mignard-autoportrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="711" decoding="async" height="304" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Mignard-autoportrait.jpg/240px-Mignard-autoportrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Mignard-autoportrait.jpg/360px-Mignard-autoportrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Mignard-autoportrait.jpg/480px-Mignard-autoportrait.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mignard-autoportrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pierre_Mignard" title="Pierre Mignard">Pierre Mignard</a>, <i>Self-portrait</i>, between 1670 and 1690, oil on canvas, 235 cm × 188 cm (93 in × 74 in), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Louvre" title="The Louvre">The Louvre</a></div></div></div>
<p>For centuries, Paris has attracted artists from around the world, who arrive in the city to educate themselves and to seek inspiration from its vast pool of artistic resources and galleries. As a result, Paris has acquired a reputation as the "City of Art".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontclos2003_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontclos2003-228">[227]</a></sup> Italian artists were a profound influence on the development of art in Paris in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly in sculpture and reliefs. Painting and sculpture became the pride of the French monarchy and the French royal family commissioned many Parisian artists to adorn their palaces during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Baroque_and_Classicism" title="French Baroque and Classicism">French Baroque and Classicism</a> era. Sculptors such as <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Girardon" title="François Girardon">Girardon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Coysevox" title="Antoine Coysevox">Coysevox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Coustou" title="Nicolas Coustou">Coustou</a> acquired reputations as the finest artists in the royal court in 17th-century France. <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Mignard" title="Pierre Mignard">Pierre Mignard</a> became the first painter to King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV</a> during this period. In 1648, the <i><a href="/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_royale_de_peinture_et_de_sculpture" title="Académie royale de peinture et de sculpture">Académie royale de peinture et de sculpture</a></i> (Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture) was established to accommodate for the dramatic interest in art in the capital. This served as France's top art school until 1793.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pierre-Auguste_Renoir,_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1639" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg/240px-Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg/360px-Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg/480px-Pierre-Auguste_Renoir%2C_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pierre-Auguste_Renoir,_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Auguste_Renoir" title="Auguste Renoir">Auguste Renoir</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bal_du_moulin_de_la_Galette" title="Bal du moulin de la Galette">Bal du moulin de la Galette</a></i>, 1876, oil on canvas, 131 cm × 175 cm (52 in × 69 in), <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris was in its artistic prime in the 19th century and early 20th century, when it had a colony of artists established in the city and in art schools associated with some of the finest painters of the times: <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec" title="Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec">Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Manet" title="Édouard Manet">Édouard Manet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Claude Monet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berthe_Morisot" title="Berthe Morisot">Berthe Morisot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gauguin" title="Paul Gauguin">Paul Gauguin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir" title="Pierre-Auguste Renoir">Pierre-Auguste Renoir</a> and others. The French Revolution and political and social change in France had a profound influence on art in the capital. Paris was central to the development of <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> in art, with painters such as <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9odore_G%C3%A9ricault" title="Théodore Géricault">Géricault</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">Symbolism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauvism" title="Fauvism">Fauvism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> movements all evolved in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> In the late 19th century, many artists in the French provinces and worldwide flocked to Paris to exhibit their works in the numerous salons and expositions and make a name for themselves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPerry199519_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPerry199519-230">[229]</a></sup> Artists such as <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Pablo Picasso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri_Matisse" title="Henri Matisse">Henri Matisse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh" title="Vincent van Gogh">Vincent van Gogh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne" title="Paul Cézanne">Paul Cézanne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Metzinger" title="Jean Metzinger">Jean Metzinger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Gleizes" title="Albert Gleizes">Albert Gleizes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri_Rousseau" title="Henri Rousseau">Henri Rousseau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amedeo_Modigliani" title="Amedeo Modigliani">Amedeo Modigliani</a> and many others became associated with Paris. Picasso, living in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Le_Bateau-Lavoir" title="Le Bateau-Lavoir">Le Bateau-Lavoir</a> in <a href="/wiki/Montmartre" title="Montmartre">Montmartre</a>, painted his famous <i><a href="/wiki/Family_of_Saltimbanques" title="Family of Saltimbanques">La Famille de Saltimbanques</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Les_Demoiselles_d%27Avignon" title="Les Demoiselles d'Avignon">Les Demoiselles d'Avignon</a></i> between 1905 and 1907.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> Montmartre and <a href="/wiki/Montparnasse" title="Montparnasse">Montparnasse</a> became centres for artistic production.
</p><p>The most prestigious names of French and foreign sculptors, who made their reputation in Paris in the modern era, are <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Auguste_Bartholdi" title="Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi">Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> – <i>Liberty Enlightening the World</i>), <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">Auguste Rodin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camille_Claudel" title="Camille Claudel">Camille Claudel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Bourdelle" title="Antoine Bourdelle">Antoine Bourdelle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Landowski" title="Paul Landowski">Paul Landowski</a> (statue of <a href="/wiki/Christ_the_Redeemer_(statue)" title="Christ the Redeemer (statue)"><i>Christ the Redeemer</i></a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Aristide_Maillol" title="Aristide Maillol">Aristide Maillol</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Golden Age</a> of the <a href="/wiki/School_of_Paris" title="School of Paris">School of Paris</a> ended between the two world wars.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photography">Photography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Photography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The inventor <a href="/wiki/Nic%C3%A9phore_Ni%C3%A9pce" title="Nicéphore Niépce">Nicéphore Niépce</a> produced the first permanent photograph on a polished pewter plate in Paris in 1825. In 1839, after the death of Niépce, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Daguerre" title="Louis Daguerre">Louis Daguerre</a> patented the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daguerrotype" title="Daguerrotype">Daguerrotype</a>, which became the most common form of photography until the 1860s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> The work of <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tienne-Jules_Marey" title="Étienne-Jules Marey">Étienne-Jules Marey</a> in the 1880s contributed considerably to the development of modern photography. Photography came to occupy a central role in Parisian Surrealist activity, in the works of <a href="/wiki/Man_Ray" title="Man Ray">Man Ray</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Tabard" title="Maurice Tabard">Maurice Tabard</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHazan2011362_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHazan2011362-233">[232]</a></sup> Numerous photographers achieved renown for their photography of Paris, including <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Atget" title="Eugène Atget">Eugène Atget</a>, noted for his depictions of street scenes, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Doisneau" title="Robert Doisneau">Robert Doisneau</a>, noted for his playful pictures of people and market scenes (among which <i>Le baiser de l'hôtel de ville</i> has become iconic of the romantic vision of Paris), <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Bovis" title="Marcel Bovis">Marcel Bovis</a>, noted for his night scenes, as well as others such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacques-Henri_Lartigue" title="Jacques-Henri Lartigue">Jacques-Henri Lartigue</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cartier-Bresson" title="Henri Cartier-Bresson">Henri Cartier-Bresson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poster_art" title="Poster art">Poster art</a> also became an important art form in Paris in the late nineteenth century, through the work of <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec" title="Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec">Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jules_Ch%C3%A9ret" title="Jules Chéret">Jules Chéret</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Grasset" title="Eugène Grasset">Eugène Grasset</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adolphe_Willette" title="Adolphe Willette">Adolphe Willette</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Bonnard" title="Pierre Bonnard">Pierre Bonnard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georges_de_Feure" title="Georges de Feure">Georges de Feure</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri-Gabriel_Ibels" title="Henri-Gabriel Ibels">Henri-Gabriel Ibels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gavarni" title="Paul Gavarni">Paul Gavarni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alphonse_Mucha" title="Alphonse Mucha">Alphonse Mucha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Museums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Paris" title="List of museums in Paris">List of museums in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset,_Paris_July_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2230" data-file-width="3966" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg/330px-The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg/495px-The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg/660px-The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset%2C_Paris_July_2013.jpg 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Mus%C3%A9e_dOrsay_at_sunset,_Paris_July_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris Museums were closed for much of 2020, but gradually re-opened in 2021, with limitations on the number of visitors at a time and a requirement that visitors wear masks and show proof of vaccination.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a> received 2,8 million visitors in 2021, up from 2.7 million in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-234">[233]</a></sup> holding its position as first among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums" title="List of most-visited museums">most-visited museums</a>. Its treasures include the <i><a href="/wiki/Mona_Lisa" title="Mona Lisa">Mona Lisa</a></i> (<i>La Joconde</i>), the <a href="/wiki/Venus_de_Milo" title="Venus de Milo">Venus de Milo</a> statue, <i><a href="/wiki/Liberty_Leading_the_People" title="Liberty Leading the People">Liberty Leading the People</a></i>. The second-most visited museum in the city in 2021, with 1.5 million visitors, was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_Georges_Pompidou" title="Centre Georges Pompidou">Centre Georges Pompidou</a>, also known as Beaubourg, which houses the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_National_d%27Art_Moderne" title="Musée National d'Art Moderne">Musée National d'Art Moderne</a> The third most visited Paris museum in 2021 was the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History,_France" title="National Museum of Natural History, France">National Museum of Natural History</a> with 1,4 million visitors. It is famous for its dinosaur artefacts, mineral collections and its Gallery of Evolution. It was followed by the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a>, featuring 19th century art and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Impressionists" title="French Impressionists">French Impressionists</a>, which had one million visitors. Paris hosts one of the largest science museums in Europe, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cit%C3%A9_des_sciences_et_de_l%27industrie" title="Cité des sciences et de l'industrie">Cité des sciences et de l'industrie</a>, (984,000 visitors in 2020). The other most-visited Paris museums in 2021 were the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fondation_Louis_Vuitton" title="Fondation Louis Vuitton">Fondation Louis Vuitton</a> (691,000), the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_du_Quai_Branly_%E2%80%93_Jacques_Chirac" title="Musée du Quai Branly – Jacques Chirac">Musée du Quai Branly – Jacques Chirac</a>, featuring the indigenous art and cultures of Africa, Asia, Oceania, and the Americas. (616,000); the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Carnavalet" title="Musée Carnavalet">Musée Carnavalet</a> (History of Paris) (606,000), and the <a href="/wiki/Petit_Palais" title="Petit Palais">Petit Palais</a>, the art museum of the City of Paris (518,000).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27Orangerie" title="Musée de l'Orangerie">Musée de l'Orangerie</a>, near both the Louvre and the Orsay, also exhibits Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, including most of <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Claude Monet</a>'s large <i><a href="/wiki/Water_Lilies_(Monet_series)" title="Water Lilies (Monet series)">Water Lilies</a></i> murals. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_national_du_Moyen_%C3%82ge" title="Musée national du Moyen Âge">Musée national du Moyen Âge</a>, or Cluny Museum, presents <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">Medieval art</a>, including the famous tapestry cycle of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lady_and_the_Unicorn" title="The Lady and the Unicorn">The Lady and the Unicorn</a></i>. The <a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Guimet Museum</a>, or <i>Musée national des arts asiatiques</i>, has one of the largest collections of Asian art in Europe. There are also notable museums devoted to individual artists, including the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Picasso" title="Musée Picasso">Musée Picasso</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin" title="Musée Rodin">Musée Rodin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_national_Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix" title="Musée national Eugène Delacroix">Musée national Eugène Delacroix</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg/220px-Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg/330px-Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg/440px-Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_du_quai_Branly.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_du_Quai_Branly_%E2%80%93_Jacques_Chirac" title="Musée du Quai Branly – Jacques Chirac">Musée du quai Branly</a></div></div></div>
<p>The military history of France, from the Middle Ages to World War II, is vividly presented by displays at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27Arm%C3%A9e" title="Musée de l'Armée">Musée de l'Armée</a> at <a href="/wiki/Les_Invalides" title="Les Invalides">Les Invalides</a>, near the tomb of Napoleon. In addition to the national museums, run by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(France)" title="Ministry of Culture (France)">Ministry of Culture</a>, the City of Paris operates 14 museums, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carnavalet_Museum" title="Carnavalet Museum">Carnavalet Museum</a> on the history of Paris, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Art_Moderne_de_la_Ville_de_Paris" title="Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris">Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palais_de_Tokyo" title="Palais de Tokyo">Palais de Tokyo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maison_de_Victor_Hugo" title="Maison de Victor Hugo">House of Victor Hugo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maison_de_Balzac" title="Maison de Balzac">House of Balzac</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Catacombs_of_Paris" title="Catacombs of Paris">Catacombs of Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup> There are also notable private museums; The Contemporary Art museum of the <a href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton_Foundation" title="Louis Vuitton Foundation">Louis Vuitton Foundation</a>, designed by architect <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gehry" title="Frank Gehry">Frank Gehry</a>, opened in October 2014 in the <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Boulogne" title="Bois de Boulogne">Bois de Boulogne</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre">Theatre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Theatre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The largest opera houses of Paris are the 19th-century Opéra Garnier (historical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_National_de_Paris" title="Opéra National de Paris">Paris Opéra</a>) and modern <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_Bastille" title="Opéra Bastille">Opéra Bastille</a>; the former tends toward the more classic ballets and operas, and the latter provides a mixed repertoire of classic and modern.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010178_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010178-237">[236]</a></sup> In the middle of the 19th century, there were three other active and competing opera houses: the Opéra-Comique (which still exists), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre-Italien" title="Théâtre-Italien">Théâtre-Italien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Lyrique" title="Théâtre Lyrique">Théâtre Lyrique</a> (which in modern times changed its profile and name to <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_de_la_Ville" title="Théâtre de la Ville">Théâtre de la Ville</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchumacher199660_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchumacher199660-238">[237]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Philharmonie_de_Paris" title="Philharmonie de Paris">Philharmonie de Paris</a>, the modern symphonic concert hall of Paris, opened in January 2015. Another musical landmark is the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_des_Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Théâtre des Champs-Élysées">Théâtre des Champs-Élysées</a>, where the first performances of Diaghilev's <a href="/wiki/Ballets_Russes" title="Ballets Russes">Ballets Russes</a> took place in 1913.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="854" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png/220px-CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png/330px-CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png/440px-CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CFfacadePlacedelOpera.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Com%C3%A9die_Fran%C3%A7aise" title="Comédie Française">Comédie Française</a> (Salle Richelieu)</div></div></div>
<p>Theatre traditionally has occupied a large place in Parisian culture, and many of its most popular actors today are also stars of French television. The oldest and most famous Paris theatre is the <a href="/wiki/Com%C3%A9die-Fran%C3%A7aise" title="Comédie-Française">Comédie-Française</a>, founded in 1680. Run by the Government of France, it performs mostly French classics at the Salle Richelieu in the <a href="/wiki/Palais-Royal" title="Palais-Royal">Palais-Royal</a> at 2 rue de Richelieu, just north of the Louvre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro19961173_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro19961173-239">[238]</a></sup> Other famous theatres include the <a href="/wiki/Od%C3%A9on-Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_de_l%27Europe" title="Odéon-Théâtre de l'Europe">Odéon-Théâtre de l'Europe</a>, just north of the Luxembourg Gardens, also a state institution and theatrical landmark; the Théâtre Mogador, and the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_de_la_Ga%C3%AEt%C3%A9-Montparnasse" title="Théâtre de la Gaîté-Montparnasse">Théâtre de la Gaîté-Montparnasse</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>The music hall and <a href="/wiki/Cabaret" title="Cabaret">cabaret</a> are famous Paris institutions. The <i><a href="/wiki/Moulin_Rouge" title="Moulin Rouge">Moulin Rouge</a></i> was opened in 1889. It was highly visible because of its large red imitation windmill on its roof, and became the birthplace of the dance known as the French <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cancan" title="Cancan">Cancan</a>. It helped make famous the singers <a href="/wiki/Mistinguett" title="Mistinguett">Mistinguett</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dith_Piaf" title="Édith Piaf">Édith Piaf</a> and the painter <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec" title="Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec">Toulouse-Lautrec</a>, who made posters for the venue. In 1911, the dance hall <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olympia_Paris" title="Olympia Paris">Olympia Paris</a> invented the grand staircase as a settling for its shows, competing with its great rival, the <i><a href="/wiki/Folies_Berg%C3%A8re" title="Folies Bergère">Folies Bergère</a></i>. Its stars in the 1920s included the American singer and dancer <a href="/wiki/Josephine_Baker" title="Josephine Baker">Josephine Baker</a>. Later, Olympia Paris presented <a href="/wiki/Dalida" title="Dalida">Dalida</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edith_Piaf" title="Edith Piaf">Edith Piaf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich" title="Marlene Dietrich">Marlene Dietrich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miles_Davis" title="Miles Davis">Miles Davis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judy_Garland" title="Judy Garland">Judy Garland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grateful_Dead" title="Grateful Dead">Grateful Dead</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Casino_de_Paris" title="Casino de Paris">Casino de Paris</a> presented many famous French singers, including <a href="/wiki/Mistinguett" title="Mistinguett">Mistinguett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Chevalier" title="Maurice Chevalier">Maurice Chevalier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tino_Rossi" title="Tino Rossi">Tino Rossi</a>. Other famous Paris music halls include <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Lido" title="Le Lido">Le Lido</a></i>, on the Champs-Élysées, opened in 1946; and the <a href="/wiki/Crazy_Horse_(cabaret)" title="Crazy Horse (cabaret)">Crazy Horse Saloon</a>, featuring strip-tease, dance and magic, opened in 1951. A half dozen music halls exist today in Paris, attended mostly by visitors to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro19961005–1006_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro19961005–1006-241">[240]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Writers_in_Paris" title="Writers in Paris">Writers in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2632" data-file-width="2140" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg/170px-Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg/255px-Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg/340px-Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Victor_Hugo_by_%C3%89tienne_Carjat_1876_-_full.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">Victor Hugo</a></div></div></div>
<p>The first book printed in France, <i>Epistolae</i> ("Letters"), by Gasparinus de Bergamo (Gasparino da Barzizza), was published in Paris in 1470 by the press established by <a href="/wiki/Johann_Heynlin" title="Johann Heynlin">Johann Heynlin</a>. Since then, Paris has been the centre of the French publishing industry, the home of some of the world's best-known writers and poets, and the setting for many classic works of French literature. Almost all the books published in Paris in the Middle Ages were in Latin, rather than French. Paris did not become the acknowledged capital of French literature until the 17th century, with authors such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicolas_Boileau" title="Nicolas Boileau">Boileau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Corneille" title="Pierre Corneille">Corneille</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Fontaine" title="La Fontaine">La Fontaine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moli%C3%A8re" title="Molière">Molière</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Racine" title="Jean Racine">Racine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Perrault" title="Charles Perrault">Charles Perrault</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> several coming from the provinces, as well as the foundation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_fran%C3%A7aise" title="Académie française">Académie française</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996488_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996488-243">[242]</a></sup> In the 18th century, the literary life of Paris revolved around the cafés and salons; it was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Rousseau" title="Jean-Jacques Rousseau">Jean-Jacques Rousseau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_de_Marivaux" title="Pierre de Marivaux">Pierre de Marivaux</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Beaumarchais" title="Pierre Beaumarchais">Pierre Beaumarchais</a>.
</p><p>During the 19th century, Paris was the home and subject for some of France's greatest writers, including <a href="/wiki/Charles_Baudelaire" title="Charles Baudelaire">Charles Baudelaire</a>, <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Mallarm%C3%A9" title="Stéphane Mallarmé">Stéphane Mallarmé</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rim%C3%A9e" title="Mérimée">Mérimée</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_de_Musset" title="Alfred de Musset">Alfred de Musset</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Proust" title="Marcel Proust">Marcel Proust</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Zola" title="Émile Zola">Émile Zola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Dumas" title="Alexandre Dumas">Alexandre Dumas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Flaubert" title="Gustave Flaubert">Gustave Flaubert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guy_de_Maupassant" title="Guy de Maupassant">Guy de Maupassant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac" title="Honoré de Balzac">Honoré de Balzac</a>. Victor Hugo's <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Hunchback_of_Notre_Dame" title="The Hunchback of Notre Dame">The Hunchback of Notre Dame</a></i> inspired the renovation of its setting, the <a href="/wiki/Notre-Dame_de_Paris" title="Notre-Dame de Paris">Notre-Dame de Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> Another of Victor Hugo's works, <i><a href="/wiki/Les_Mis%C3%A9rables" title="Les Misérables">Les Misérables</a></i>, written while he was in exile outside France during the Second Empire, described the social change and political turmoil in Paris in the early 1830s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> One of the most popular of all French writers, <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">Jules Verne</a>, worked at the Theatre Lyrique and the Paris stock exchange, while he did research for his stories at the National Library.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Added cite for 1988 edition, page may be incorrect. (June 2019)">verification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="491" data-file-width="571" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG/220px-Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG/330px-Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG/440px-Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the 20th century, the Paris literary community was dominated by figures such as <a href="/wiki/Colette" title="Colette">Colette</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Gide" title="André Gide">André Gide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mauriac" title="François Mauriac">François Mauriac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Malraux" title="André Malraux">André Malraux</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Camus" title="Albert Camus">Albert Camus</a>, and, after World War II, by <a href="/wiki/Simone_de_Beauvoir" title="Simone de Beauvoir">Simone de Beauvoir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a>. Between the wars it was the home of many important expatriate writers, including <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Hemingway" title="Ernest Hemingway">Ernest Hemingway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Beckett" title="Samuel Beckett">Samuel Beckett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Asturias" title="Miguel Ángel Asturias">Miguel Ángel Asturias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alejo_Carpentier" title="Alejo Carpentier">Alejo Carpentier</a> and, <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Uslar_Pietri" title="Arturo Uslar Pietri">Arturo Uslar Pietri</a>. The winner of the 2014 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Modiano" title="Patrick Modiano">Patrick Modiano</a> (who lives in Paris), based most of his literary work on the depiction of the city during World War II and the 1960s–1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris is a city of books and bookstores. In the 1970s, 80 percent of French-language publishing houses were found in Paris, almost all on the Left Bank in the 5th, 6th and 7th arrondissements. Since that time, because of high prices, some publishers have moved out to the less expensive areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996840_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996840-248">[247]</a></sup> It is also a city of small bookstores. There are about 150 bookstores in the 5th arrondissement alone, plus another 250 book stalls along the Seine. Small Paris bookstores are protected against competition from discount booksellers by French law; books, even e-books, cannot be discounted more than five percent below their publisher's cover price.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_in_Paris" title="Music in Paris">Music in Paris</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_music_in_Paris" title="History of music in Paris">History of music in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Olympia_facade.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2256" data-file-width="1496" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Olympia_facade.jpg/170px-Olympia_facade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Olympia_facade.jpg/255px-Olympia_facade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Olympia_facade.jpg/340px-Olympia_facade.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Olympia_facade.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Olympia_(Paris)" title="Olympia (Paris)">Olympia</a>, a famous music hall</div></div></div>
<p>In the late 12th century, a school of <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">polyphony</a> was established at Notre-Dame. Among the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trouv%C3%A8res" title="Trouvères">Trouvères</a> of northern France, a group of Parisian aristocrats became known for their poetry and songs. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Troubadours" title="Troubadours">Troubadours</a>, from the south of France, were also popular. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Francis_I_of_France" title="Francis I of France">François I</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_music" title="Renaissance music">Renaissance era</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lute" title="Lute">lute</a> became popular in the French court. The French royal family and courtiers "disported themselves in masques, ballets, allegorical dances, recitals, and opera and comedy", and a national musical printing house was established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Baroque_music" title="Baroque music">Baroque-era</a>, noted composers included <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lully" title="Jean-Baptiste Lully">Jean-Baptiste Lully</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean-Philippe_Rameau" title="Jean-Philippe Rameau">Jean-Philippe Rameau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Couperin" title="François Couperin">François Couperin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Conservatoire_de_Paris" title="Conservatoire de Paris"><i>Conservatoire de Musique de Paris</i></a> was founded in 1795.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDamschroederWilliams1990157_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDamschroederWilliams1990157-250">[249]</a></sup> By 1870, Paris had become an important centre for symphony, ballet and operatic music.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Romantic_music" title="Romantic music">Romantic-era</a> composers (in Paris) include <a href="/wiki/Hector_Berlioz" title="Hector Berlioz">Hector Berlioz</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/La_Symphonie_fantastique" title="La Symphonie fantastique">La Symphonie fantastique</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Charles_Gounod" title="Charles Gounod">Charles Gounod</a> (<a href="/wiki/Faust_(opera)" title="Faust (opera)"><i>Faust</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Camille_Saint-Sa%C3%ABns" title="Camille Saint-Saëns">Camille Saint-Saëns</a> (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samson_et_Delilah" title="Samson et Delilah">Samson et Delilah</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9o_Delibes" title="Léo Delibes">Léo Delibes</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Lakm%C3%A9" title="Lakmé">Lakmé</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Jules_Massenet" title="Jules Massenet">Jules Massenet</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Tha%C3%AFs" title="Thaïs">Thaïs</a></i>), among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011_229-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichelin2011-229">[228]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Georges_Bizet%27s" title="Georges Bizet's">Georges Bizet's</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Carmen" title="Carmen">Carmen</a></i> premiered 3 March 1875. <i>Carmen</i> has since become one of the most popular and frequently-performed operas in the classical <a href="/wiki/Western_canon" title="Western canon">canon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McClary_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-McClary-251">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> Among the <a href="/wiki/Impressionism_in_music" title="Impressionism in music">Impressionist</a> composers who created new works for piano, orchestra, opera, chamber music and other musical forms, stand in particular, <a href="/wiki/Claude_Debussy" title="Claude Debussy">Claude Debussy</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Suite_bergamasque" title="Suite bergamasque">Suite bergamasque</a></i>, and its well-known third movement, <i>Clair de lune</i>, <a href="/wiki/La_mer_(Debussy)" title="La mer (Debussy)"><i>La Mer</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Pell%C3%A9as_et_M%C3%A9lisande_(opera)" title="Pelléas et Mélisande (opera)"><i>Pelléas et Mélisande</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Erik_Satie" title="Erik Satie">Erik Satie</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Gymnop%C3%A9dies" title="Gymnopédies">Gymnopédies</a></i>, "<a href="/wiki/Je_te_veux" title="Je te veux">Je te veux</a>", <i><a href="/wiki/Gnossiennes" title="Gnossiennes">Gnossiennes</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Parade_(ballet)" title="Parade (ballet)">Parade</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Ravel" title="Maurice Ravel">Maurice Ravel</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Miroirs" title="Miroirs">Miroirs</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bol%C3%A9ro" title="Boléro">Boléro</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/La_valse" title="La valse">La valse</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/L%27heure_espagnole" title="L'heure espagnole">L'heure espagnole</a></i>). Several foreign-born composers, such as <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="Frédéric Chopin">Frédéric Chopin</a> (<a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>), <a href="/wiki/Franz_Liszt" title="Franz Liszt">Franz Liszt</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>), <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Offenbach" title="Jacques Offenbach">Jacques Offenbach</a> (<a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>), <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Paganini" title="Niccolò Paganini">Niccolò Paganini</a> (<a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a> (<a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>), established themselves or made significant contributions both with their works and their influence in Paris.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1837" data-file-width="1434" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg/170px-Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg/255px-Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg/340px-Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Aznavour_May_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Charles_Aznavour" title="Charles Aznavour">Charles Aznavour</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bal-musette" title="Bal-musette">Bal-musette</a> is a style of French music and dance that first became popular in Paris in the 1870s and 1880s; by 1880 Paris had some 150 dance halls in the working-class neighbourhoods of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDregni200419_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDregni200419-253">[252]</a></sup> Patrons danced the <a href="/wiki/Bourr%C3%A9e" title="Bourrée">bourrée</a> to the accompaniment of the <a href="/wiki/Cabrette" title="Cabrette">cabrette</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Bellows" title="Bellows">bellows</a>-blown <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bagpipe" title="Bagpipe">bagpipe</a> locally called a "musette") and often the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vielle_%C3%A0_roue" title="Vielle à roue">vielle à roue</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hurdy-gurdy" title="Hurdy-gurdy">hurdy-gurdy</a>) in the cafés and bars of the city. Parisian and Italian musicians who played the <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">accordion</a> adopted the style and established themselves in Auvergnat bars especially in the 19th arrondissement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDregni200832_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDregni200832-254">[253]</a></sup> and the romantic sounds of the accordion has since become one of the musical icons of the city. Paris became a major centre for <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and still attracts jazz musicians from all around the world to its clubs and cafés.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMroue2006260_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMroue2006260-255">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>Paris is the spiritual home of <a href="/wiki/Gypsy_jazz" title="Gypsy jazz">gypsy jazz</a> in particular, and many of the Parisian jazzmen who developed in the first half of the 20th century began by playing Bal-musette in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDregni200832_254-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDregni200832-254">[253]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Django_Reinhardt" title="Django Reinhardt">Django Reinhardt</a> rose to fame in Paris, having moved to the 18th arrondissement in a caravan as a young boy, and performed with violinist <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Grappelli" title="Stéphane Grappelli">Stéphane Grappelli</a> and their <a href="/wiki/Quintette_du_Hot_Club_de_France" title="Quintette du Hot Club de France">Quintette du Hot Club de France</a> in the 1930s and 1940s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gjazz_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gjazz-256">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>Immediately after the War the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint-Germain-des-Pres" title="Saint-Germain-des-Pres">Saint-Germain-des-Pres</a> quarter and the nearby Saint-Michel quarter became home to many small jazz clubs, mostly found in cellars because of a lack of space; these included the Caveau des Lorientais, the Club Saint-Germain, the Rose Rouge, the Vieux-Colombier, and the most famous, <a href="/wiki/Le_Tabou" title="Le Tabou">Le Tabou</a>. They introduced Parisians to the music of <a href="/wiki/Claude_Luter" title="Claude Luter">Claude Luter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Vian" title="Boris Vian">Boris Vian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sydney_Bechet" title="Sydney Bechet">Sydney Bechet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mezz_Mezzrow" title="Mezz Mezzrow">Mezz Mezzrow</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Henri_Salvador" title="Henri Salvador">Henri Salvador</a>. Most of the clubs closed by the early 1960s, as musical tastes shifted toward rock and roll.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBezbakh2004872_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBezbakh2004872-257">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the finest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manouche" title="Manouche">manouche</a> musicians in the world are found here playing the cafés of the city at night.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gjazz_256-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gjazz-256">[255]</a></sup> Some of the more notable jazz venues include the New Morning, Le Sunset, La Chope des Puces and Bouquet du Nord.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMroue2006260_255-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMroue2006260-255">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gjazz_256-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gjazz-256">[255]</a></sup> Several yearly festivals take place in Paris, including the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Jazz_Festival" title="Paris Jazz Festival">Paris Jazz Festival</a> and the rock festival <a href="/wiki/Rock_en_Seine" title="Rock en Seine">Rock en Seine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Orchestre_de_Paris" title="Orchestre de Paris">Orchestre de Paris</a> was established in 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andante_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-andante-259">[258]</a></sup> On 19 December 2015, Paris and other worldwide fans commemorated the 100th anniversary of the birth of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edith_Piaf" title="Edith Piaf">Edith Piaf</a>—a cabaret singer-songwriter and actress who became widely regarded as France's national <a href="/wiki/Chanson" title="Chanson">chanteuse</a>, as well as being one of France's greatest international stars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yahoomusicbio_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-yahoomusicbio-260">[259]</a></sup> Other singers—of similar style—include <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Chevalier" title="Maurice Chevalier">Maurice Chevalier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Aznavour" title="Charles Aznavour">Charles Aznavour</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yves_Montand" title="Yves Montand">Yves Montand</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Charles_Trenet" title="Charles Trenet">Charles Trenet</a>.
</p><p>Paris has a big <a href="/wiki/French_hip_hop" title="French hip hop">hip hop</a> scene. This music became popular during the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> The presence of a large African and Caribbean community helped to its development, it gave a voice, a political and social status for many minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Cinema">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_Paris" title="List of films set in Paris">List of films set in Paris</a></div>
