<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="606" data-file-width="987" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg/210px-Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg/315px-Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg/420px-Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salah_Zulfikar%26Sabah.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Salah_Zulfikar" title="Salah Zulfikar">Salah Zulfikar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sabah_(singer)" title="Sabah (singer)">Sabah</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Paris_and_Love" title="Paris and Love">Paris and Love</a></i> (1972)</div></div></div>
<p>The movie industry was born in Paris when <a href="/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re" title="Auguste and Louis Lumière">Auguste and Louis Lumière</a> projected the first motion picture for a paying audience at the Grand Café on 28 December 1895.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> Many of Paris's concert/dance halls were transformed into cinemas when the media became popular beginning in the 1930s. Later, most of the largest cinemas were divided into multiple, smaller rooms. Paris's largest cinema room today is in the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Rex" title="Grand Rex">Grand Rex</a> theatre with 2,700 seats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup><br/>Big multiplex cinemas have been built since the 1990s. UGC Ciné Cité Les Halles with 27 screens, MK2 Bibliothèque with 20 screens and UGC Ciné Cité Bercy with 18 screens are among the largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>Parisians tend to share the same movie-going trends as many of the world's global cities, with cinemas primarily dominated by Hollywood-generated film entertainment. <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_France" title="Cinema of France">French cinema</a> comes a close second, with major directors (<i>réalisateurs</i>) such as <a href="/wiki/Claude_Lelouch" title="Claude Lelouch">Claude Lelouch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean-Luc_Godard" title="Jean-Luc Godard">Jean-Luc Godard</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Luc_Besson" title="Luc Besson">Luc Besson</a>, and the more slapstick/popular genre with director <a href="/wiki/Claude_Zidi" title="Claude Zidi">Claude Zidi</a> as an example. European and Asian films are also widely shown and appreciated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> On 2 February 2000, Philippe Binant realised the first <a href="/wiki/Digital_cinema" title="Digital cinema">digital cinema</a> projection in Europe, with the DLP CINEMA technology developed by <a href="/wiki/Texas_Instruments" title="Texas Instruments">Texas Instruments</a>, in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Restaurants_and_cuisine"><span class="anchor" id="Cuisine"></span>Restaurants and cuisine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Restaurants and cuisine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3667" data-file-width="5500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg/220px-Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg/330px-Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg/440px-Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brasserie_Vagenende_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dining room of the Vagenende</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_Zimmer,_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3700" data-file-width="5550" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg/220px-Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg/330px-Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg/440px-Le_Zimmer%2C_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_Zimmer,_restaurant_in_Paris.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Le Zimmer, on the <a href="/wiki/Place_du_Ch%C3%A2telet" title="Place du Châtelet">Place du Châtelet</a>, where <a href="/wiki/G%C3%A9o_Lef%C3%A8vre" title="Géo Lefèvre">Géo Lefèvre</a> first suggested the idea of a <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a> to <a href="/wiki/Henri_Desgrange" title="Henri Desgrange">Henri Desgrange</a> in 1902</div></div></div>
<p>Since the late 18th century, Paris has been famous for its restaurants and <i><a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">haute cuisine</a></i>, food meticulously prepared and artfully presented. A luxury restaurant, La Taverne Anglaise, opened in 1786 in the arcades of the <a href="/wiki/Palais-Royal" title="Palais-Royal">Palais-Royal</a> by <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Beauvilliers" title="Antoine Beauvilliers">Antoine Beauvilliers</a>; it featured an elegant dining room, an extensive menu, linen tablecloths, a large wine list and well-trained waiters; it became a model for future Paris restaurants. The restaurant <a href="/wiki/Le_Grand_V%C3%A9four" title="Le Grand Véfour">Le Grand Véfour</a> in the Palais-Royal dates from the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro19961136–1138_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro19961136–1138-269">[268]</a></sup> The famous Paris restaurants of the 19th century, including the Café de Paris, the <a href="/wiki/Au_Rocher_de_Cancale" title="Au Rocher de Cancale">Rocher de Cancale</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Anglais" title="Café Anglais">Café Anglais</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maison_dor%C3%A9e_(Paris)" title="Maison dorée (Paris)">Maison Dorée</a> and the Café Riche, were mostly located near the theatres on the <a href="/wiki/Boulevard_des_Italiens" title="Boulevard des Italiens">Boulevard des Italiens</a>; they were immortalised in the novels of Balzac and <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Zola" title="Émile Zola">Émile Zola</a>. Several of the best-known restaurants in Paris today appeared during the <i><a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Belle Époque</a></i>, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maxim%27s_Paris" title="Maxim's Paris">Maxim's</a> on Rue Royale, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ledoyen" title="Ledoyen">Ledoyen</a> in the gardens of the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tour_d%27Argent" title="Tour d'Argent">Tour d'Argent</a> on the Quai de la Tournelle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro19961137_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro19961137-270">[269]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, due to Paris's cosmopolitan population, every French regional cuisine and almost every national cuisine in the world can be found there; the city has more than 9,000 restaurants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDominé2014_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDominé2014-271">[270]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin Guide</a> has been a standard guide to French restaurants since 1900, awarding its highest award, three stars, to the best restaurants in France. In 2018, of the 27 Michelin three-star restaurants in France, ten are located in Paris. These include both restaurants which serve classical French cuisine, such as <a href="/wiki/L%27Ambroisie" title="L'Ambroisie">L'Ambroisie</a> in the Place des Vosges, and those which serve non-traditional menus, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%27Astrance" title="L'Astrance">L'Astrance</a>, which combines French and Asian cuisines. Several of France's most famous chefs, including <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Gagnaire" title="Pierre Gagnaire">Pierre Gagnaire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alain_Ducasse" title="Alain Ducasse">Alain Ducasse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yannick_All%C3%A9no" title="Yannick Alléno">Yannick Alléno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alain_Passard" title="Alain Passard">Alain Passard</a>, have three-star restaurants in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lesdeuxmagots.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2250" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Lesdeuxmagots.jpg/220px-Lesdeuxmagots.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Lesdeuxmagots.jpg/330px-Lesdeuxmagots.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Lesdeuxmagots.jpg/440px-Lesdeuxmagots.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lesdeuxmagots.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Les_Deux_Magots" title="Les Deux Magots">Les Deux Magots</a> café on Boulevard Saint-Germain</div></div></div>
<p>In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The <a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">café</a> arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the beverage was first brought from Turkey, and by the 18th century Parisian cafés were centres of the city's political and cultural life. The <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Procope" title="Café Procope">Café Procope</a> on the Left Bank dates from this period. In the 20th century, the cafés of the Left Bank, especially <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_de_la_Rotonde" title="Café de la Rotonde">Café de la Rotonde</a> and <a href="/wiki/Le_D%C3%B4me_Caf%C3%A9" title="Le Dôme Café">Le Dôme Café</a> in Montparnasse and <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_de_Flore" title="Café de Flore">Café de Flore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Les_Deux_Magots" title="Les Deux Magots">Les Deux Magots</a> on Boulevard Saint Germain, all still in business, were important meeting places for painters, writers and philosophers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro19961137_270-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro19961137-270">[269]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Bistro" title="Bistro">bistro</a> is a type of eating place loosely defined as a neighbourhood restaurant with a modest decor and prices and a regular clientele and a congenial atmosphere. Its name is said to have come in 1814 from the Russian soldiers who occupied the city; "bistro" means "quickly" in <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, and they wanted their meals served rapidly so they could get back to their encampment. Real bistros are increasingly rare in Paris, due to rising costs, competition from cheaper ethnic restaurants, and different eating habits of Parisian diners.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996715_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996715-274">[273]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Brasserie" title="Brasserie">brasserie</a> originally was a tavern located next to a brewery, which served beer and food at any hour. Beginning with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Exposition_of_1867" title="Paris Exposition of 1867">Paris Exposition of 1867</a>; it became a popular kind of restaurant which featured beer and other beverages served by young women in the national costume associated with the beverage, particularly German costumes for beer. Now brasseries, like cafés, serve food and drinks throughout the day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFierro1996773_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFierro1996773-275">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion">Fashion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Fashion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fashion_in_Paris" title="Fashion in Paris">Fashion in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="933" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg/170px-Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg/255px-Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg/340px-Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Magdalena_Frackowiak.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magdalena_Frackowiak" title="Magdalena Frackowiak">Magdalena Frackowiak</a> at <a href="/wiki/Paris_Fashion_Week" title="Paris Fashion Week">Paris Fashion Week</a> (Fall 2011)</div></div></div>
<p>Since the 19th century, Paris has been an international <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capital</a>, particularly in the domain of <a href="/wiki/Haute_couture" title="Haute couture">haute couture</a> (clothing hand-made to order for private clients).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> It is home to some of the largest fashion houses in the world, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Dior_S.A." title="Christian Dior S.A.">Dior</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chanel" title="Chanel">Chanel</a>, as well as many other well-known and more contemporary fashion designers, such as <a href="/wiki/Karl_Lagerfeld" title="Karl Lagerfeld">Karl Lagerfeld</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Gaultier" title="Jean-Paul Gaultier">Jean-Paul Gaultier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yves_Saint_Laurent_(designer)" title="Yves Saint Laurent (designer)">Yves Saint Laurent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Givenchy" title="Givenchy">Givenchy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Christian_Lacroix" title="Christian Lacroix">Christian Lacroix</a>. <a href="/wiki/Paris_Fashion_Week" title="Paris Fashion Week">Paris Fashion Week</a>, held in January and July in the <a href="/wiki/Carrousel_du_Louvre" title="Carrousel du Louvre">Carrousel du Louvre</a> among other renowned city locations, is one of the top four events on the international fashion calendar. The other fashion capitals of the world, <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>, <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a>, also host fashion weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup> Moreover, Paris is also the home of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">cosmetics</a> company: <a href="/wiki/L%27Or%C3%A9al" title="L'Oréal">L'Oréal</a> as well as three of the top five global makers of luxury fashion accessories: <a href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton" title="Louis Vuitton">Louis Vuitton</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herm%C3%A9s" title="Hermés">Hermés</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cartier_(jeweler)" title="Cartier (jeweler)">Cartier</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[278]</a></sup> Most of the major fashion designers have their showrooms along the <a href="/wiki/Avenue_Montaigne" title="Avenue Montaigne">Avenue Montaigne</a>, between the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a> and the Seine.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_festivals">Holidays and festivals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Holidays and festivals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2666" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg/170px-French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg/255px-French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg/340px-French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_Republican_Guard_Bastille_Day_2007_n1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republican_Guard_(France)" title="Republican Guard (France)">Republican Guards</a> parading on <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">Bastille Day</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">Bastille Day</a>, a celebration of the storming of the Bastille in 1789, the biggest festival in the city, is a military parade taking place every year on 14 July on the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a>, from the <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a> to <a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Concorde" title="Place de la Concorde">Place de la Concorde</a>. It includes a <a href="/wiki/Flypast" title="Flypast">flypast</a> over the Champs Élysées by the <a href="/wiki/Patrouille_de_France" title="Patrouille de France">Patrouille de France</a>, a parade of military units and equipment, and a display of fireworks in the evening, the most spectacular being the one at the Eiffel Tower.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004204_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004204-280">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some other yearly festivals are <a href="/wiki/Paris-Plages" title="Paris-Plages">Paris-Plages</a>, a festive event that lasts from mid-July to mid-August when the Right Bank of the Seine is converted into a temporary beach with sand, deck chairs and palm trees;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004204_280-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlackmoreMcConnachie2004204-280">[279]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/European_Heritage_Days" title="European Heritage Days">Journées du Patrimoine</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%AAte_de_la_Musique" title="Fête de la Musique">Fête de la Musique</a>, Techno Parade, <a href="/wiki/Nuit_Blanche" title="Nuit Blanche">Nuit Blanche</a>, Cinéma au clair de lune, Printemps des rues, Festival d'automne, and Fête des jardins. The <a href="/wiki/Paris_Carnival" title="Paris Carnival">Carnaval de Paris</a>, one of the oldest festivals in Paris, dates back to the Middle Ages.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Paris" title="Education in Paris">Education in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1503" data-file-width="1506" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg/220px-Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg/330px-Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg/440px-Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_75005_Rue_Saint-Jacques_La_Sorbonne_facade_01c.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The main building of the former <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">University of Paris</a> is now used by classes from <a href="/wiki/Sorbonne_University" title="Sorbonne University">Sorbonne University</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Sorbonne_University" title="New Sorbonne University">New Sorbonne University</a> and other autonomous campuses.</div></div></div>
<p>Paris is the département with the highest proportion of highly educated people. In 2009, around 40 percent of Parisians held a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Licence_(France)" title="Licence (France)">licence</a></i>-level diploma or higher, the highest proportion in France,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> while 13 percent have no diploma, the third-lowest percentage in France. Education in Paris and the Île-de-France region employs approximately 330,000 people, 170,000 of whom are teachers and professors teaching approximately 2.9 million children and students in around 9,000 primary, secondary, and higher education schools and institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-idf_education_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-idf_education-282">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p>
The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">University of Paris</a>, founded in the 12th century, is often called the <a href="/wiki/Sorbonne" title="Sorbonne">Sorbonne</a> after one of its original medieval colleges. It was broken up into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_institutions_in_the_Paris_region" title="List of universities and institutions in the Paris region">thirteen autonomous universities</a> in 1970, following the <a href="/wiki/May_68" title="May 68">student demonstrations in 1968</a>. Most of the campuses today are in the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Quarter,_Paris" title="Latin Quarter, Paris">Latin Quarter</a> where the old university was located, while others are scattered around the city and the suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECombeau2013213–214_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECombeau2013213–214-283">[282]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme,_54_boulevard_Raspail,_Paris_6e_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg/220px-Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg/330px-Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg/440px-Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme%2C_54_boulevard_Raspail%2C_Paris_6e_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maison_des_sciences_de_l%27homme,_54_boulevard_Raspail,_Paris_6e_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_des_hautes_%C3%A9tudes_en_sciences_sociales" title="École des hautes études en sciences sociales">École des hautes études en sciences sociales</a> (EHESS), France's most prestigious university in the social sciences, is headquartered in the 6th arrondissement.</div></div></div>
<p>The Paris region hosts France's highest concentration of the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grandes_%C3%A9coles" title="Grandes écoles">grandes écoles</a></i> – 55 specialised centres of higher-education outside or inside the public university structure. The prestigious public universities are usually considered <i><a href="/wiki/Grands_%C3%A9tablissements" title="Grands établissements">grands établissements</a></i>. Most of the <i>grandes écoles</i> were relocated to the suburbs of Paris in the 1960s and 1970s, in new campuses much larger than the old campuses within the crowded City of Paris, though the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Normale_Sup%C3%A9rieure" title="École Normale Supérieure">École Normale Supérieure</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_Sciences_et_Lettres_University" title="Paris Sciences et Lettres University">PSL University</a> has remained on rue d'Ulm in the <a href="/wiki/5th_arrondissement_of_Paris" title="5th arrondissement of Paris">5th arrondissement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> There are a high number of engineering schools, led by the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Sciences_et_Lettres_University" title="Paris Sciences et Lettres University">PSL University</a> (which comprises several colleges such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_mines_de_Paris" title="École nationale supérieure des mines de Paris">École des Mines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chimie_ParisTech" title="Chimie ParisTech">École nationale supérieure de chimie</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_pratique_des_hautes_%C3%A9tudes" title="École pratique des hautes études">École Pratique des Hautes Études</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paris_Dauphine_University" title="Paris Dauphine University">Paris-Dauphine</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Paris-Saclay_University" title="Paris-Saclay University">Paris-Saclay University</a> (which comprises several colleges such as <a href="/wiki/AgroParisTech" title="AgroParisTech">AgroParisTech</a>, <a href="/wiki/CentraleSup%C3%A9lec" title="CentraleSupélec">CentraleSupélec</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_Paris-Saclay" title="École normale supérieure Paris-Saclay">ENS Paris-Saclay</a>) the <a href="/wiki/Polytechnic_Institute_of_Paris" title="Polytechnic Institute of Paris">Polytechnic Institute of Paris</a> (which comprises several colleges such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Polytechnique" title="École Polytechnique">École Polytechnique</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_t%C3%A9l%C3%A9communications" title="École nationale supérieure des télécommunications">Télécom Paris</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Nationale_de_la_Statistique_et_de_l%27Administration_Economique" title="École Nationale de la Statistique et de l'Administration Economique">École nationale de la statistique et de l'administration économique</a>) and also independent colleges such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_des_ponts_et_chauss%C3%A9es" title="École nationale des ponts et chaussées">École des Ponts et Chaussées</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers" title="École nationale supérieure d'arts et métiers">Arts et Métiers</a>. There are also many business schools, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HEC_School_of_Management" title="HEC School of Management">HEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/INSEAD" title="INSEAD">INSEAD</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_sciences_%C3%A9conomiques_et_commerciales" title="École supérieure des sciences économiques et commerciales">ESSEC</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ESCP_Europe" title="ESCP Europe">ESCP Europe</a>. While <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_d%27administration" title="École nationale d'administration">ENA</a>, the school training higher-level civil servants, has been relocated from Paris to <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>, three of the most prestigious social sciences universities, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Institut_d%27Etudes_Politiques_de_Paris" title="Institut d'Etudes Politiques de Paris">Sciences Po</a> (7th arrondissement), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_des_hautes_%C3%A9tudes_en_sciences_sociales" title="École des hautes études en sciences sociales">École des hautes études en sciences sociales</a> (6th arrondissement), and <a href="/wiki/Paris_Dauphine_University" title="Paris Dauphine University">Paris-Dauphine</a> (16th arrondissement) are still located in Paris. The Parisian school of journalism <a href="/wiki/CELSA_Paris" title="CELSA Paris">CELSA</a> department of <a href="/wiki/Sorbonne_University" title="Sorbonne University">Sorbonne University</a> is located in Neuilly-sur-Seine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> Paris is also home to several of France's most famous high-schools such as <a href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Louis-le-Grand" title="Lycée Louis-le-Grand">Lycée Louis-le-Grand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Henri-IV" title="Lycée Henri-IV">Lycée Henri-IV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Janson_de_Sailly" title="Lycée Janson de Sailly">Lycée Janson de Sailly</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Condorcet" title="Lycée Condorcet">Lycée Condorcet</a>. The <a href="/wiki/INSEP" title="INSEP">National Institute of Sport and Physical Education</a>, located in the 12th arrondissement, is both a physical education institute and high-level training centre for elite athletes.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Libraries">Libraries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Libraries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Libraries_in_Paris" title="Libraries in Paris">Libraries in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg/220px-Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg/330px-Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg/440px-Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salle_de_lecture_Bibliotheque_Sainte-Genevieve_n01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sainte-Genevi%C3%A8ve_Library" title="Sainte-Geneviève Library">Sainte-Geneviève Library</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France" title="Bibliothèque nationale de France">Bibliothèque nationale de France</a></i> (BnF) operates public libraries in Paris, among them the François Mitterrand Library, Richelieu Library, Louvois, Opéra Library, and <a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_de_l%27Arsenal" title="Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal">Arsenal Library</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup> There are three public libraries in the 4th arrondissement. The <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B4tel_de_Sens" title="Hôtel de Sens">Forney Library</a>, in the Marais district, is dedicated to the decorative arts; the Arsenal Library occupies a former military building, and has a large collection on French literature; and the <a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_historique_de_la_ville_de_Paris" title="Bibliothèque historique de la ville de Paris">Bibliothèque historique de la ville de Paris</a>, also in Le Marais, contains the Paris historical research service. The <a href="/wiki/Sainte-Genevi%C3%A8ve_Library" title="Sainte-Geneviève Library">Sainte-Geneviève Library</a> is in 5th arrondissement; designed by <a href="/wiki/Henri_Labrouste" title="Henri Labrouste">Henri Labrouste</a> and built in the mid-1800s, it contains a rare book and manuscript division.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Woodward2006_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Woodward2006-287">[286]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_Mazarine" title="Bibliothèque Mazarine">Bibliothèque Mazarine</a>, in the 6th arrondissement, is the oldest public library in France. The <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9diath%C3%A8que_Musicale_Mahler" title="Médiathèque Musicale Mahler">Médiathèque Musicale Mahler</a> in the 8th arrondissement opened in 1986 and contains collections related to music. The François Mitterrand Library (nicknamed <i>Très Grande Bibliothèque</i>) in the 13th arrondissement was completed in 1994 to a design of <a href="/wiki/Dominique_Perrault" title="Dominique Perrault">Dominique Perrault</a> and contains four glass towers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Woodward2006_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-Woodward2006-287">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are several academic libraries and archives in Paris. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_de_la_Sorbonne" title="Bibliothèque de la Sorbonne">Sorbonne Library</a> in the 5th arrondissement is the largest university library in Paris. In addition to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sorbonne_(building)" title="Sorbonne (building)">Sorbonne</a> location, there are branches in Malesherbes, Clignancourt-Championnet, Michelet-<a href="/wiki/Institut_d%27Art_et_d%27Arch%C3%A9ologie" title="Institut d'Art et d'Archéologie">Institut d'Art et d'Archéologie</a>, Serpente-Maison de la Recherche, and Institut des Etudes Ibériques.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup> Other academic libraries include Interuniversity Pharmaceutical Library, Leonardo da Vinci University Library, Paris School of Mines Library, and the René Descartes University Library.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nd.edu_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-nd.edu-289">[288]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Sports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg/220px-Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg/330px-Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg/440px-Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_Paris_Saint-Germain_re%C3%A7oit_l%27AS_Monaco_au_Parc_en_Coupe_de_France_le_26_avril_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Parc_des_Princes" title="Parc des Princes">Parc des Princes</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris's most popular sport clubs are the <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> club <a href="/wiki/Paris_Saint-Germain_F.C." title="Paris Saint-Germain F.C.">Paris Saint-Germain F.C.</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> clubs <a href="/wiki/Stade_Fran%C3%A7ais" title="Stade Français">Stade Français</a> and <a href="/wiki/Racing_92" title="Racing 92">Racing 92</a>, the last of which is based just outside the city proper. The 80,000-seat <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_France" title="Stade de France">Stade de France</a>, built for the <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">1998 FIFA World Cup</a>, is located just north of Paris in the commune of <a href="/wiki/Saint-Denis,_Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Saint-Denis, Seine-Saint-Denis">Saint-Denis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010300–301_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010300–301-290">[289]</a></sup> It is used for football, rugby union and track and field athletics. It hosts the <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France national football team</a> for friendlies and major tournaments qualifiers, annually hosts the <a href="/wiki/France_national_rugby_union_team" title="France national rugby union team">French national rugby team</a>'s home matches of the <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Six Nations Championship</a>, and hosts several important matches of the Stade Français rugby team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010300–301_290-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010300–301-290">[289]</a></sup> In addition to Paris Saint-Germain F.C., the city has a number of other professional and amateur football clubs: <a href="/wiki/Paris_FC" title="Paris FC">Paris FC</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Star_Saint-Ouen" title="Red Star Saint-Ouen">Red Star</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RCF_Paris" title="RCF Paris">RCF Paris</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stade_Fran%C3%A7ais_Paris_(football)" title="Stade Français Paris (football)">Stade Français Paris</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg/220px-Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg/330px-Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg/440px-Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tour_de_france_2010_-_Champs_Elys%C3%A9es_n10.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>2010 Tour de France, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Champs_%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs Élysées">Champs Élysées</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris hosted the <a href="/wiki/1900_Summer_Olympics" title="1900 Summer Olympics">1900</a> and <a href="/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics" title="1924 Summer Olympics">1924</a> Summer Olympics and will host the <a href="/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics" title="2024 Summer Olympics">2024 Summer Olympics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paralympic_Games" title="Paralympic Games">Paralympic Games</a>.
</p><p>The city also hosted the finals of the <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">1938 FIFA World Cup</a> (at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir" title="Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir">Stade Olympique de Colombes</a>), as well as the <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">1998 FIFA World Cup</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2007_Rugby_World_Cup_Final" title="2007 Rugby World Cup Final">2007 Rugby World Cup Final</a> (both at the Stade de France). Three <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League_Finals" title="UEFA Champions League Finals">UEFA Champions League Finals</a> in the current century have also been played in the Stade de France: the <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2000 UEFA Champions League Final">2000</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2006 UEFA Champions League Final">2006</a> and <a href="/wiki/2022_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2022 UEFA Champions League Final">2022</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup> Paris has most recently been the host for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">UEFA Euro 2016</a>, both at the <a href="/wiki/Parc_des_Princes" title="Parc des Princes">Parc des Princes</a> in the city proper and also at Stade de France, with the latter hosting the opening match and final.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The final stage of the most famous <a href="/wiki/Road_bicycle_racing" title="Road bicycle racing">bicycle racing</a> in the world, <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a>, always finishes in Paris. Since 1975, the race has <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es_stage_in_the_Tour_de_France" title="Champs-Élysées stage in the Tour de France">finished on the Champs-Elysées</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_(3577046132).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2144" data-file-width="3876" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg/250px-Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg/375px-Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg/500px-Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_%283577046132%29.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Court_Philippe_Chatrier_Ana_Ivanovic_2009_(3577046132).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a>, played on red <a href="/wiki/Clay_court" title="Clay court">clay</a>, is one of four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slams</a> in professional tennis.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">Tennis</a> is another popular sport in Paris and throughout France; the <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a>, held every year on the red clay of the Roland Garros National Tennis Centre,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> is one of the four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> events of the world professional tennis tour. The 17,000-seat <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AccorHotels_Arena" title="AccorHotels Arena">Bercy Arena</a> (officially named <i>AccorHotels Arena</i> and formerly known as the <i>Palais Omnisports de Paris-Bercy</i>) is the venue for the annual <a href="/wiki/Paris_Masters" title="Paris Masters">Paris Masters</a> <a href="/wiki/ATP_Tour" title="ATP Tour">ATP Tour</a> tennis tournament and has been a frequent site of national and international tournaments in basketball, boxing, cycling, handball, ice hockey, show jumping and other sports. The Bercy Arena also hosted the <a href="/wiki/2017_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2017 IIHF World Championship">2017 IIHF World Ice Hockey Championship</a>, together with <a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a>, Germany. The final stages of the FIBA <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_1951" title="EuroBasket 1951">EuroBasket 1951</a> and <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_1999" title="EuroBasket 1999">EuroBasket 1999</a> were also played in Paris, the latter at the Palais Omnisports de Paris-Bercy.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a> team <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Levallois_Metropolitans" title="Levallois Metropolitans">Levallois Metropolitans</a> plays some of its games at the 4,000 capacity <a href="/wiki/Stade_Pierre_de_Coubertin_(Paris)" title="Stade Pierre de Coubertin (Paris)">Stade Pierre de Coubertin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> Another top-level professional team, <a href="/wiki/Nanterre_92" title="Nanterre 92">Nanterre 92</a>, plays in <a href="/wiki/Nanterre" title="Nanterre">Nanterre</a>.
</p><p>In 2023, a professional <a href="/wiki/American_football" title="American football">American football</a> team will start in the city<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> joining the <a href="/wiki/European_League_of_Football" title="European League of Football">European league of football</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Infrastructure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Paris" title="Transport in Paris">Transport in Paris</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_railway_stations_in_Paris" title="List of railway stations in Paris">List of railway stations in Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG/220px-Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG/330px-Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG/440px-Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gare_du_Nord_night_Paris_FRA_002.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Gare_du_Nord" title="Gare du Nord">Gare du Nord</a> railway station is the busiest in Europe.</div></div></div>
<p>Paris is a major rail, highway, and air transport hub. <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_Mobilit%C3%A9s" title="Île-de-France Mobilités">Île-de-France Mobilités</a> (IDFM), formerly the Syndicat des transports d'Île-de-France (STIF) and before that the Syndicat des transports parisiens (STP), oversees the transit network in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stif_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-stif-296">[295]</a></sup> The syndicate coordinates public transport and contracts it out to the <a href="/wiki/RATP_Group" title="RATP Group">RATP</a> (operating 347 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bus_(RATP)" title="Bus (RATP)">bus</a> lines, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Métro</a>, eight tramway lines, and sections of the RER), the <a href="/wiki/SNCF" title="SNCF">SNCF</a> (operating suburban rails, one tramway line and the other sections of the RER) and the <a href="/wiki/Optile" title="Optile">Optile</a> consortium of private operators managing 1,176 bus lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2018 INSEE survey, a large majority of Parisians (64.3 percent) use public transport to get to work. Only 10.6 percent commuted to work by automobile. 10.5 percent walked or used roller skates; 5.5 percent commuted by bicycle; and 4.4 percent commuted by motorbike.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bike lanes are being doubled, while electric car incentives are being created. The French capital is banning the most polluting automobiles from key districts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Railways">Railways</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Railways">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_railway_stations_in_Paris" title="List of railway stations in Paris">List of railway stations in Paris</a></div>
<p>A central hub of the national rail network, Paris's six major railway stations (<a href="/wiki/Gare_du_Nord" title="Gare du Nord">Gare du Nord</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gare_de_l%27Est" title="Gare de l'Est">Gare de l'Est</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gare_de_Lyon" title="Gare de Lyon">Gare de Lyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Austerlitz" title="Gare d'Austerlitz">Gare d'Austerlitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gare_Montparnasse" title="Gare Montparnasse">Gare Montparnasse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gare_Saint-Lazare" title="Gare Saint-Lazare">Gare Saint-Lazare</a>) and a minor one (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gare_de_Bercy" title="Gare de Bercy">Gare de Bercy</a>) are connected to three networks: the <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">TGV</a> serving four <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed rail</a> lines, the normal speed <a href="/wiki/Corail_(train)" title="Corail (train)">Corail</a> trains, and the suburban rails (<a href="/wiki/Transilien" title="Transilien">Transilien</a>).
</p>
<h4><span id="M.C3.A9tro.2C_RER_and_tramway"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Métro,_RER_and_tramway">Métro, RER and tramway</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Métro, RER and tramway">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris Métro</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_Express_R%C3%A9gional" title="Réseau Express Régional">Réseau Express Régional</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tramways_in_%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Tramways in Île-de-France">Tramways in Île-de-France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg/220px-Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg/330px-Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg/440px-Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paris_-_Station_de_m%C3%A9tro_Abbesses_-_PA00086748_-_001.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris Métro</a> is the busiest subway network in the European Union.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the inauguration of its first line in 1900, Paris's Métro network has grown to become the city's most widely used local transport system; today it carries about 5.23 million passengers daily<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> through 16 lines, 308 stations (391 stops) and 226.9 km (141.0 mi) of rails. Superimposed on this is a '<a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9seau_Express_R%C3%A9gional" title="Réseau Express Régional">regional express network</a>', the RER, whose five lines (A, B, C, D, and E), 257 stops and 587 km (365 mi) of rails connect Paris to more distant parts of the urban area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283-302">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over €26.5 billion will be invested over the next 15 years to extend the Métro network into the suburbs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283-302">[301]</a></sup> with notably the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Paris_Express" title="Grand Paris Express">Grand Paris Express</a> project.
</p><p>In addition, the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Paris region</a> is served by a light rail network of nine lines, the tramway: <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_1" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 1">Line T1</a> runs from Asnières-Gennevilliers to Noisy-le-Sec, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_2" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 2">Line T2</a> runs from Pont de Bezons to Porte de Versailles, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Lines_3a_and_3b" title="Île-de-France tramway Lines 3a and 3b">Line T3a</a> runs from Pont du Garigliano to Porte de Vincennes, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Lines_3a_and_3b" title="Île-de-France tramway Lines 3a and 3b">Line T3b</a> runs from Porte de Vincennes to Porte d'Asnières, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_5" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 5">Line T5</a> runs from Saint-Denis to Garges-Sarcelles, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_6" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 6">Line T6</a> runs from Châtillon to Viroflay, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_7" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 7">Line T7</a> runs from Villejuif to Athis-Mons, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_8" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 8">Line T8</a> runs from Saint-Denis to Épinay-sur-Seine and Villetaneuse, all of which are operated by the <a href="/wiki/RATP_Group" title="RATP Group">RATP Group</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France_tramway_Line_4" title="Île-de-France tramway Line 4">line T4</a> runs from Bondy RER to Aulnay-sous-Bois, which is operated by the state rail carrier SNCF.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283_302-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283-302">[301]</a></sup> Five new light rail lines are currently in various stages of development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Air">Air</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Air">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CDG_P1020431.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/CDG_P1020431.JPG/220px-CDG_P1020431.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/CDG_P1020431.JPG/330px-CDG_P1020431.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/CDG_P1020431.JPG/440px-CDG_P1020431.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CDG_P1020431.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 2020 <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle_Airport" title="Charles de Gaulle Airport">Paris–Charles de Gaulle Airport</a> was the busiest airport in Europe and the eighth-busiest airport in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Paris is a major international air transport hub with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic">5th busiest airport system in the world</a>. The city is served by three commercial international airports: <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle_Airport" title="Charles de Gaulle Airport">Paris–Charles de Gaulle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orly_Airport" title="Orly Airport">Paris–Orly</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beauvais%E2%80%93Till%C3%A9_Airport" title="Beauvais–Tillé Airport">Beauvais–Tillé Airport</a>. Together these three airports recorded traffic of 112 million passengers in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> There is also one <a href="/wiki/General_aviation" title="General aviation">general aviation</a> airport, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_%E2%80%93_Le_Bourget_Airport" title="Paris – Le Bourget Airport">Paris-Le Bourget</a>, historically the oldest Parisian airport and closest to the city centre, which is now used only for private business flights and air shows.
</p><p>Orly Airport, located in the southern suburbs of Paris, replaced Le Bourget as the principal airport of Paris from the 1950s to the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> Charles de Gaulle Airport, located on the edge of the northern suburbs of Paris, opened to commercial traffic in 1974 and became the busiest Parisian airport in 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> For the year 2017 it was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic">5th busiest airport in the world by international traffic</a> and it is the hub for the nation's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> <a href="/wiki/Air_France" title="Air France">Air France</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283_302-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010278–283-302">[301]</a></sup> Beauvais-Tillé Airport, located 69 kilometres (43 miles) north of Paris's city centre, is used by charter airlines and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Low-cost_carriers" title="Low-cost carriers">low-cost carriers</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Ryanair" title="Ryanair">Ryanair</a>.
</p><p>Domestically, air travel between Paris and some of France's largest cities such as <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a> has been in a large measure replaced by <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed rail</a> due to the opening of several high-speed <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">TGV</a> rail lines from the 1980s. For example, after the <a href="/wiki/LGV_M%C3%A9diterran%C3%A9e" title="LGV Méditerranée">LGV Méditerranée</a> opened in 2001, air traffic between Paris and Marseille declined from 2,976,793 passengers in 2000 to 1,502,196 passengers in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-domestic_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-domestic-309">[308]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/LGV_Est" title="LGV Est">LGV Est</a> opened in 2007, air traffic between Paris and Strasbourg declined from 1,006,327 passengers in 2006 to 157,207 passengers in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-domestic_309-1"><a href="#cite_note-domestic-309">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>Internationally, air traffic has increased markedly in recent years between Paris and the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Gulf</a> airports, the emerging nations of Africa, Russia, Turkey, Portugal, Italy, and <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>, whereas noticeable decline has been recorded between Paris and the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a>, Egypt, Tunisia, and Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-international1_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-international1-310">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-international2_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-international2-311">[310]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Motorways">Motorways</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Motorways">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ParisRingRoads_A104.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/ParisRingRoads_A104.svg/220px-ParisRingRoads_A104.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/ParisRingRoads_A104.svg/330px-ParisRingRoads_A104.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/ParisRingRoads_A104.svg/440px-ParisRingRoads_A104.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ParisRingRoads_A104.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ring roads of Paris</div></div></div>
<p>The city is also the most important hub of France's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motorway" title="Motorway">motorway</a> network, and is surrounded by three orbital freeways: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C3%A9riph%C3%A9rique_(Paris)" title="Périphérique (Paris)">Périphérique</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201069_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand201069-98">[97]</a></sup> which follows the approximate path of 19th-century fortifications around Paris, the <a href="/wiki/A86_autoroute" title="A86 autoroute">A86</a> motorway in the inner suburbs, and finally the <a href="/wiki/Francilienne" title="Francilienne">Francilienne</a> motorway in the outer suburbs. Paris has an extensive road network with over 2,000 km (1,243 mi) of highways and motorways.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Waterways">Waterways</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Waterways">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The Paris region is the most active water transport area in France, with most of the cargo handled by <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Port_of_Paris" title="Autonomous Port of Paris">Ports of Paris</a> in facilities located around Paris. The rivers <a href="/wiki/Loire" title="Loire">Loire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rh%C3%B4ne" title="Rhône">Rhône</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meuse" title="Meuse">Meuse</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Scheldt" title="Scheldt">Scheldt</a> can be reached by canals connecting with the Seine, which include the <a href="/wiki/Canal_Saint-Martin" title="Canal Saint-Martin">Canal Saint-Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canal_Saint-Denis" title="Canal Saint-Denis">Canal Saint-Denis</a>, and the Canal de l'Ourcq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJefferson2009114_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJefferson2009114-312">[311]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cycling">Cycling</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Cycling">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1753" data-file-width="2632" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG/220px-Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG/330px-Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG/440px-Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Station_Velib_DSC_3497.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lib%27" title="Vélib'">Vélib'</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Bastille" title="Place de la Bastille">Place de la Bastille</a></div></div></div>
<p>There are 440 km (270 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Cycling_in_Paris" title="Cycling in Paris">cycle paths and routes</a> in Paris. These include <i>piste cyclable</i> (bike lanes separated from other traffic by physical barriers such as a kerb) and <i>bande cyclable</i> (a bicycle lane denoted by a painted path on the road). Some 29 km (18 mi) of specially marked bus lanes are free to be used by cyclists, with a protective barrier protecting against encroachments from vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHart2004355_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHart2004355-313">[312]</a></sup> Cyclists have also been given the right to ride in both directions on certain one-way streets. Paris offers a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Community_bicycle_program" title="Community bicycle program">bike sharing</a> system called <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lib%27" title="Vélib'">Vélib'</a> with more than 20,000 public bicycles distributed at 1,800 parking stations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERand2010165_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERand2010165-314">[313]</a></sup> which can be rented for short and medium distances including <a href="/wiki/One-way_traffic" title="One-way traffic">one way</a> trips.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electricity">Electricity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Electricity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Electricity is provided to Paris through a peripheral grid fed by multiple sources. In 2012, around 50% of electricity generated in the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Île-de-France</a> came from cogeneration energy plants located near the outer limits of the <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_France" title="Regions of France">region</a>; other energy sources included thermal power (35%), waste incineration (9% – with cogeneration plants, these provide the city in heat as well), methane gas (5%), hydraulics (1%), solar power (0.1%) and a negligible amount of wind power (0.034 GWh).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prod_electrique_IDF_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-prod_electrique_IDF-315">[314]</a></sup> A quarter of the city's <a href="/wiki/District_heating" title="District heating">district heating</a> is to come from a plant in <a href="/wiki/Saint-Ouen-sur-Seine" title="Saint-Ouen-sur-Seine">Saint-Ouen-sur-Seine</a>, burning a 50/50-mix of coal and 140,000 tonnes of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wood_pellets" title="Wood pellets">wood pellets</a> from the United States per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_and_sanitation">Water and sanitation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Water and sanitation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="576" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg/220px-Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg/330px-Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg/440px-Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ile_de_la_Cite_from_Pont_de_la_Tournelle.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of the Seine, the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_de_la_Cit%C3%A9" title="Île de la Cité">Île de la Cité</a> and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bateau_Mouche" title="Bateau Mouche">Bateau Mouche</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris in its early history had only the rivers Seine and <a href="/wiki/Bi%C3%A8vre_(river)" title="Bièvre (river)">Bièvre</a> for water. From 1809, the <a href="/wiki/Canal_de_l%27Ourcq" title="Canal de l'Ourcq">Canal de l'Ourcq</a> provided Paris with water from less-polluted rivers to the north-east of the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> From 1857, the civil engineer <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Belgrand" title="Eugène Belgrand">Eugène Belgrand</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a>, oversaw the construction of a series of new aqueducts that brought water from locations all around the city to several reservoirs built atop the Capital's highest points of elevation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurchell197193_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurchell197193-318">[317]</a></sup> From then on, the new reservoir system became Paris's principal source of drinking water, and the remains of the old system, pumped into lower levels of the same reservoirs, were from then on used for the cleaning of Paris's streets. This system is still a major part of Paris's modern water-supply network. Today Paris has more than 2,400 km (1,491 mi) of underground passageways<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sewers_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-sewers-319">[318]</a></sup> dedicated to the evacuation of Paris's liquid wastes.
</p><p>In 1982, Mayor Chirac introduced the motorcycle-mounted <a href="/wiki/Motocrotte" title="Motocrotte">Motocrotte</a> to remove <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dog_feces" title="Dog feces">dog faeces</a> from Paris streets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> The project was abandoned in 2002 for a new and better enforced local law, under the terms of which dog owners can be fined up to €500 for not removing their dog faeces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution" title="Air pollution">air pollution</a> in Paris, from the point of view of <a href="/wiki/Particulates" title="Particulates">particulate matter</a> (PM10), is the highest in France with 38 μg/m<sup>3</sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup> From the point of view of nitrogen dioxide pollution, Paris has one of the highest levels in the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks_and_gardens">Parks and gardens</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Parks and gardens">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_parks_and_gardens_in_Paris" title="List of parks and gardens in Paris">List of parks and gardens in Paris</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Parks_and_Gardens_of_Paris" title="History of Parks and Gardens of Paris">History of Parks and Gardens of Paris</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont,_22_April_2007.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1071" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg/220px-Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg/330px-Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg/440px-Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont%2C_22_April_2007.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont,_22_April_2007.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The lawns of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parc_des_Buttes-Chaumont" title="Parc des Buttes-Chaumont">Parc des Buttes-Chaumont</a> on a sunny day</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG/220px-Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG/330px-Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG/440px-Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saint-Cloud_-_Passerelle_de_l%27Avre_008.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Passerelle de l'Avre, crossing the Seine and establishing a link between the <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Boulogne" title="Bois de Boulogne">Bois de Boulogne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint-Cloud" title="Saint-Cloud">Saint-Cloud</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-Seine" title="Hauts-de-Seine">Hauts-de-Seine</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paris today has more than 421 municipal parks and gardens, covering more than 3,000 hectares and containing more than 250,000 trees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJarrassé20076_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJarrassé20076-324">[323]</a></sup> Two of Paris's oldest and most famous gardens are the <a href="/wiki/Tuileries_Garden" title="Tuileries Garden">Tuileries Garden</a> (created in 1564 for the <a href="/wiki/Tuileries_Palace" title="Tuileries Palace">Tuileries Palace</a> and redone by <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Le_N%C3%B4tre" title="André Le Nôtre">André Le Nôtre</a> between 1664 and 1672)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010125_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010125-325">[324]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luxembourg_Garden" title="Luxembourg Garden">Luxembourg Garden</a>, for the <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg_Palace" title="Luxembourg Palace">Luxembourg Palace</a>, built for <a href="/wiki/Marie_de%27_Medici" title="Marie de' Medici">Marie de' Medici</a> in 1612, which today houses the <a href="/wiki/Senate_(France)" title="Senate (France)">Senate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010208_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawrenceGondrand2010208-326">[325]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Jardin_des_plantes" title="Jardin des plantes">Jardin des plantes</a></i> was the first botanical garden in Paris, created in 1626 by Louis XIII's doctor <a href="/wiki/Guy_de_La_Brosse" title="Guy de La Brosse">Guy de La Brosse</a> for the cultivation of medicinal plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup>
